ï»¿THE WOOD BEYOND [THE WORLD]1-the world

CHAPTER I : OF [GOLDEN WALTER]35-walter AND [[HIS]35-walter FATHER]86-his father

Awhile ago there was [a young man]87-a young man dwelling in [a great and goodly city by [the sea]89-the sea which had to name [Langton]35-walter on [Holm]3-holm]88-a great and goodly city by the sea which had to name langton on holm . [He]87-a young man was but of five and twenty winters , [a fair - faced man]90-a fair - faced man , yellow - haired , tall and strong ; rather wiser than foolisher than [young men are mostly wo nt]91-young men are mostly wo nt ; [a valiant youth]92-a valiant youth , and [a kind]93-a kind ; [not of many words but courteous of speech]94-not of many words but courteous of speech ; [no roisterer]95-no roisterer , nought masterful , but peaceable and knowing how to forbear : in a fray [a perilous foe]96-a perilous foe , and [a trusty war - fellow]97-a trusty war - fellow . [[His]35-walter father]86-his father , with whom [he]35-walter was dwelling when this tale begins , was [a great merchant , richer than [a baron of [the land]101-the land]100-a baron of the land , [a head - man of the greatest of the Lineages of [Langton]35-walter]102-a head - man of the greatest of the lineages of langton]99-a great merchant , richer than a baron of the land , a head - man of the greatest of the lineages of langton , and [a captain of the Porte]103-a captain of the porte ; [he]87-a young man was of [the Lineage of the Goldings]104-the lineage of the goldings , therefore was [he]87-a young man called [Bartholomew Golden]36-bartholomew golden , and [[his]86-his father son]105-his son [Golden Walter]35-walter .

Now [ye]106-ye may well deem that such a youngling as this was looked upon by [all]107-all as [a lucky man without a lack]108-a lucky man without a lack ; but there was this flaw in [his]35-walter lot , whereas [he]35-walter had fallen into the toils of love of [a woman exceeding fair]109-a woman exceeding fair , and had taken [her]109-a woman exceeding fair to [wife]110-wife , [she]109-a woman exceeding fair nought unwilling as it seemed . But when [they]111-they had been wedded some six months [he]35-walter found by manifest tokens , that [his]35-walter fairness was not so much to [her]109-a woman exceeding fair but that [she]109-a woman exceeding fair must seek to the foulness of one worser than [he]35-walter in all ways ; wherefore [his]35-walter rest departed from [him]35-walter , whereas [he]35-walter hated [her]109-a woman exceeding fair for [her]109-a woman exceeding fair untruth and [her]109-a woman exceeding fair hatred of [him]35-walter ; yet would the sound of [her]109-a woman exceeding fair voice , as [she]109-a woman exceeding fair came and went in [the house]112-the house , make [his]35-walter heart beat ; and the sight of [her]109-a woman exceeding fair stirred desire within [him]35-walter , so that [he]35-walter longed for [her]109-a woman exceeding fair to be sweet and kind with [him]35-walter , and deemed that , might it be so , [he]35-walter should forget all the evil gone by . But it was not so ; for ever when [she]109-a woman exceeding fair saw [him]35-walter , [her]109-a woman exceeding fair face changed , and [her]109-a woman exceeding fair hatred of [him]35-walter became manifest , and howsoever [she]109-a woman exceeding fair were sweet with [others]113-others , with [him]35-walter [she]109-a woman exceeding fair was hard and sour .

So this went on a while till [the chambers of [[his]35-walter father]86-his father 's house]114-the chambers of his father 's house , yea [the very streets of [the city]117-the city]116-the very streets of the city , became loathsome to [him]35-walter ; and yet [he]35-walter called to mind that [the world]118-the world was wide and [he]35-walter but [a young man]87-a young man . So on a day as [he]35-walter sat with [[his]35-walter father]86-his father alone , [he]35-walter spake to [him]86-his father and said : " [Father]1546-father , [I]35-walter was on [the quays]1547-the quays even now , and [I]35-walter looked on the ships that were nigh boun , and [thy]86-his father sign [I]35-walter saw on [a tall ship that seemed to [me]35-walter nighest boun]1548-a tall ship that seemed to me nighest boun . Will it be long ere [she]86-his father sail ? "[35-walter]

" Nay , "[86-his father] said [[his]35-walter father]86-his father , " [that ship]1549-that ship , which hight [the Katherine]1550-the katherine , will [they]1550-the katherine warp out of [the haven]1551-the haven in two days ' time . But why askest [thou]86-his father of [her]86-his father ? "[86-his father]

" The shortest word is best , [father]1546-father , "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter , " and this it is , that [I]35-walter would depart in [the said ship]1553-the said ship and see [other lands]1554-other lands . "[35-walter]

" [Yea]1555-yea and whither , [son]1556-son ? "[122-the merchant] said [the merchant]122-the merchant .

" [Whither]37-whither [she]86-his father goeth , "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter , " for [I]35-walter am ill at ease at [home]1557-home , as [thou]86-his father wottest , [father]1546-father . "[35-walter]

[The merchant]122-the merchant held [his]122-the merchant peace awhile , and looked hard on [[his]122-the merchant son]105-his son , for there was strong love between [them]125-we ; but at last [he]122-the merchant said : " Well , [son]1556-son , maybe it were best for [thee]1556-son ; but maybe also [we]125-we shall not meet again . "[122-the merchant]

" Yet if [we]125-we do meet , [father]1546-father , then shalt [thou]86-his father see [a new man in [me]122-the merchant]1561-a new man in me . "[122-the merchant]

" Well , "[36-bartholomew golden] said [Bartholomew]36-bartholomew golden , " at least [I]36-bartholomew golden know on whom to lay the loss of [thee]1556-son , and when [thou]86-his father art gone , for [thou]86-his father shalt have thine own way herein , [she]1556-son shall no longer abide in [[my]36-bartholomew golden house]1562-my house . Nay , but it were for the strife that should arise thenceforth betwixt [her]1556-son kindred and [ours]125-we , it should go somewhat worse with [her]1556-son than that . "[36-bartholomew golden]

Said [Walter]35-walter : " [I]35-walter pray [thee]1556-son shame [her]1556-son not more than needs must be , lest , so doing , [thou]86-his father shame both [me]35-walter and [thyself]1563-thyself also . "[35-walter]

[Bartholomew]36-bartholomew golden held [his]36-bartholomew golden peace again for a while ; then [he]36-bartholomew golden said : " Goeth [she]1556-son with [child]1564-child , [[my]36-bartholomew golden son]1565-my son ? "[36-bartholomew golden]

[Walter]35-walter reddened , and said : " [I]35-walter wot not ; nor of whom [the child]1566-the child may be . "[35-walter] Then [they]126-they both sat silent , till [Bartholomew]36-bartholomew golden spake , saying : " The end of it is , [son]1556-son , that this is Monday , and that [thou]86-his father shalt go aboard in the small hours of Wednesday ; and meanwhile [I]36-bartholomew golden shall look to it that [thou]86-his father go not away empty - handed ; [the skipper of [the Katherine]1550-the katherine]1568-the skipper of the katherine is [a good man]1570-a good man and true , and knows [the seas]1571-the seas well ; and [[my]36-bartholomew golden servant]1572-my servant [Robert the Low]38-robert the low , who is [clerk of the lading]1573-clerk of the lading , is trustworthy and wise , and as [myself]36-bartholomew golden in all matters that look towards [chaffer]1574-chaffer . [The Katherine]5-the katherine is new and stout - builded , and should be lucky , whereas [she]5-the katherine is under the ward of [her]5-the katherine who is [the saint called upon in [the church where [thou]86-his father wert christened]1576-the church where thou wert christened , and [myself]36-bartholomew golden before [thee]86-his father]1575-the saint called upon in the church where thou wert christened , and myself before thee ; and [[thy]86-his father mother]1577-thy mother , and [[my]36-bartholomew golden father]1578-my father and [mother]1579-mother all lie under [the chancel thereof]1580-the chancel thereof , as [thou]86-his father wottest . "[36-bartholomew golden]

Therewith [the elder]127-the elder rose up and went [his]127-the elder ways about [his]127-the elder business , and there was no more said betwixt [him]127-the elder and [[his]127-the elder son]105-his son on this matter .

CHAPTER II : [GOLDEN WALTER]35-walter TAKES SHIP TO SAIL [THE SEAS]4-the seas

When [Walter]35-walter went down to [the Katherine]1550-the katherine next morning , there was [the skipper Geoffrey]130-the skipper geoffrey , who did [him]35-walter reverence , and made [him]35-walter all cheer , and showed [him]35-walter [his]35-walter room aboard [ship]131-ship , and the plenteous goods which [[his]35-walter father]86-his father had sent down to [the quays]1547-the quays already , such haste as [he]35-walter had made . [Walter]35-walter thanked [[his]35-walter father]86-his father 's love in [his]35-walter heart , but otherwise took little heed to [his]35-walter affairs , but wore away the time about [the haven]1551-the haven , gazing listlessly on the ships that were making them ready outward , or unlading , and [the mariners]136-the mariners and [aliens]137-aliens coming and going : and all these were to [him]35-walter as the curious images woven on a tapestry .

At last when [he]35-walter had wellnigh come back again to [the Katherine]5-the katherine , [he]35-walter saw there [a tall ship]138-a tall ship , which [he]35-walter had scarce noted before , [a ship all - boun , which had [her]138-a tall ship boats]139-a ship all - boun , which had her boats out , and [men sitting to the oars]140-men sitting to the oars thereof ready to tow [her]138-a tall ship outwards when [the hawser should be cast off]141-the hawser should be cast off , and by seeming [[her]138-a tall ship mariners]142-her mariners were but abiding for [some one or other]143-some one or other to come aboard .

So [Walter]35-walter stood idly watching [the said ship]1553-the said ship , and as [he]35-walter looked , [lo ! folk]145-lo ! folk passing [him]35-walter toward [the gangway]146-the gangway . [These were three]147-these were three ; first came [a dwarf , dark - brown of hue and hideous , with long arms and ears exceeding great and dog - teeth that stuck out like the fangs of a wild beast]148-a dwarf , dark - brown of hue and hideous , with long arms and ears exceeding great and dog - teeth that stuck out like the fangs of a wild beast . [He]148-a dwarf , dark - brown of hue and hideous , with long arms and ears exceeding great and dog - teeth that stuck out like the fangs of a wild beast was clad in a rich coat of yellow silk , and bare in [his]148-a dwarf , dark - brown of hue and hideous , with long arms and ears exceeding great and dog - teeth that stuck out like the fangs of a wild beast hand a crooked bow , and was girt with a broad sax .

After [him]148-a dwarf , dark - brown of hue and hideous , with long arms and ears exceeding great and dog - teeth that stuck out like the fangs of a wild beast came [a maiden , young by seeming , of scarce twenty summers]149-a maiden , young by seeming , of scarce twenty summers ; fair of face as a flower ; grey - eyed , brown - haired , with lips full and red , slim and gentle of body . [Simple]40-simple was [her]149-a maiden , young by seeming , of scarce twenty summers array , of a short and strait green gown , so that on [her]149-a maiden , young by seeming , of scarce twenty summers right ankle was clear to see an iron ring .

Last of the three was [a lady]150-a lady , tall and stately , so radiant of visage and glorious of raiment , that it were hard to say what like [she]150-a lady was ; for scarce might the eye gaze steady upon [her]150-a lady exceeding beauty ; yet must [every son of Adam who found [himself]151-every son of adam who found himself anigh her anigh [her]150-a lady]151-every son of adam who found himself anigh her , lift up [his]151-every son of adam who found himself anigh her eyes again after [he]151-every son of adam who found himself anigh her had dropped them , and look again on [her]150-a lady , and yet again and yet again . Even so did [Walter]35-walter , and as [the three]152-the three passed by [him]35-walter , it seemed to [him]35-walter as if all [the other folk there about]153-the other folk there about had vanished and were nought ; nor had [he]35-walter any vision before [his]35-walter eyes of any looking on [them]152-the three , save [himself]35-walter alone . [They]152-the three went over [the gangway]146-the gangway into [the ship]155-the ship , and [he]35-walter saw [them]152-the three go along [the deck]156-the deck till [they]152-the three came to [the house on [the poop]158-the poop]157-the house on the poop , and entered [it]157-the house on the poop and were gone from [his]35-walter sight .

There [he]35-walter stood staring , till little by little [the thronging people of [the quays]1547-the quays]159-the thronging people of the quays came into [his]35-walter eye - shot again ; then [he]35-walter saw how [the hawser]161-the hawser was cast off and [the boats]162-the boats fell to tugging [the big ship]163-the big ship toward [the harbour]164-the harbour - mouth with hale and how of [men]165-men . Then the sail fell down from [the yard]166-the yard and was sheeted [home]1557-home and filled with the fair wind as [the ship]155-the ship 's bows ran up on the first green wave outside [the haven]1551-the haven . Even therewith [the shipmen]170-the shipmen cast abroad a banner , whereon was done in a green field a grim wolf ramping up against [a maiden]171-a maiden , and so went [the ship]155-the ship upon [her]155-the ship way .

[Walter]35-walter stood awhile staring at [[her]155-the ship empty place where the waves ran into [the haven - mouth]174-the haven - mouth]173-her empty place where the waves ran into the haven - mouth , and then turned aside and toward [the Katherine]5-the katherine ; and at first [he]35-walter was minded to go ask shipmaster Geoffrey of what [he]35-walter knew concerning [the said ship]1553-the said ship and [[her]1553-the said ship alien wayfarers]176-her alien wayfarers ; but then it came into [his]35-walter mind , that all this was but an imagination or dream of the day , and that [he]35-walter were best to leave it untold to any . So therewith [he]35-walter went [his]35-walter way from [the water - side]177-the water - side , and through [the streets]178-the streets unto [[[his]35-walter father]86-his father 's house]180-his father 's house ; but when [he]35-walter was but a little way thence , and the door was before [him]35-walter , [him-]35-walter seemed for a moment of time that [he]35-walter beheld those three coming out down the steps of stone and into [the street]181-the street ; to wit [the dwarf]182-the dwarf , [the maiden]183-the maiden , and [the stately lady]184-the stately lady : but when [he]35-walter stood still to abide [their]185-their coming , and looked toward [them]185-their , lo ! there was nothing before [him]35-walter save [the goodly house of [Bartholomew Golden]36-bartholomew golden]186-the goodly house of bartholomew golden , and [three children and a cur dog playing about the steps thereof]187-three children and a cur dog playing about the steps thereof , and about [him]35-walter were [four or five passers - by]188-four or five passers - by going about [their]188-four or five passers - by business . Then was [he]35-walter all confused in [his]35-walter mind , and knew not what to make of it , whether [those whom [he]35-walter had seemed to see pass [aboard ship]190-aboard ship]189-those whom he had seemed to see pass aboard ship were but images of a dream , or [children of Adam in very flesh]191-children of adam in very flesh .

Howsoever , [he]35-walter entered [the house]112-the house , and found [[his]35-walter father]86-his father in [the chamber]194-the chamber , and fell to speech with [him]86-his father about [their]185-their matters ; but for all that [he]35-walter loved [[his]35-walter father]86-his father , and worshipped [him]86-his father as [a wise and valiant man]196-a wise and valiant man , yet at that hour [he]35-walter might not hearken the words of [his]35-walter mouth , so much was [his]35-walter mind entangled in the thought of [those three]197-those three , and they were ever before [his]35-walter eyes , as if they had been painted on a table by the best of [limners]198-limners . And of [the two women]199-the two women [he]35-walter thought exceeding much , and cast no wyte upon [himself]35-walter for running after the desire of [strange women]200-strange women . For [he]35-walter said to [himself]35-walter that [he]35-walter desired not either of the twain ; nay , [he]35-walter might not tell which of [the twain]201-the twain , [the maiden]183-the maiden or [the stately queen]203-the stately queen , were clearest to [his]35-walter eyes ; but sore [he]35-walter desired to see both of [them]199-the two women again , and to know what [they]199-the two women were .

So wore the hours till the Wednesday morning , and it was time that [he]35-walter should bid farewell to [[his]35-walter father]86-his father and get aboard [ship]131-ship ; but [[his]35-walter father]86-his father led [him]35-walter down to [the quays]1547-the quays and on to [the Katherine]5-the katherine , and there [Walter]35-walter embraced [him]35-walter , not without tears and forebodings ; for [his]35-walter heart was full . Then presently [the old man]208-the old man went aland ; the gangway was unshipped , the hawsers cast off ; the oars of [the towing - boats]209-the towing - boats splashed in the dark water , the sail fell down from [the yard]166-the yard , and was sheeted [home]1557-home , and out plunged [the Katherine]5-the katherine into [the misty sea]212-the misty sea and rolled up [the grey slopes]213-the grey slopes , casting abroad [her]5-the katherine ancient withal , whereon was beaten the token of [Bartholomew Golden]36-bartholomew golden , to wit a B and a G to the right and the left , and thereabove a cross and a triangle rising from the midst .

[Walter]35-walter stood on the stern and beheld , yet more with the mind of [him]35-walter than with [his]35-walter eyes ; for it all seemed but the double of what [the other ship]214-the other ship had done ; and the thought of it as if [the twain]201-the twain were as beads strung on one string and led away by it into [the same place]216-the same place , and thence to go in the like order , and so on again and again , and never to draw nigher to each other .

CHAPTER III : [WALTER]35-walter HEARETH TIDINGS OF THE DEATH OF [[HIS]35-walter FATHER]86-his father

Fast sailed [the Katherine]5-the katherine over [the seas]1571-the seas , and nought befell to tell of , either to [herself]5-the katherine or [[her]5-the katherine crew]219-her crew . [She]5-the katherine came to [one cheaping - town]220-one cheaping - town and then to another , and so on to a third and a fourth ; and at each was buying and selling after the manner of chapmen ; and [Walter]35-walter not only looked on the doings of [[[his]35-walter father]86-his father 's folk]222-his father 's folk , but lent a hand , what [he]35-walter might , to help [them]222-his father 's folk in all matters , whether it were in [seaman]223-seaman 's craft , or in [chaffer]1574-chaffer . And the further [he]35-walter went and the longer the time wore , the more [he]35-walter was eased of [his]35-walter old trouble wherein [[his]35-walter wife]225-his wife and [[her]5-the katherine treason]226-her treason had to do .

But as for the other trouble , to wit [his]35-walter desire and longing to come up with those three , it yet flickered before [him]35-walter ; and though [he]35-walter had not seen [them]222-his father 's folk again as one sees [people]227-people in [the streets]178-the streets , and as if [he]35-walter might touch [them]222-his father 's folk if [he]35-walter would , yet were [their]222-his father 's folk images often before [his]35-walter mind 's eye ; and yet , as time wore , not so often , nor so troublously ; and forsooth both to those about [him]35-walter and to [himself]35-walter , [he]35-walter seemed as [a man]229-a man well healed of [his]35-walter melancholy mood .

Now [they]230-they left that fourth stead , and sailed over [the seas]1571-the seas and came to a fifth , [a very great and fair city]232-a very great and fair city , which [they]230-they had made more than seven months from [[Langton]35-walter on [Holm]3-holm]233-langton on holm ; and by this time was [Walter]35-walter taking heed and joyance in such things as were toward in [that fair city]234-that fair city , so far from [[his]35-walter kindred]235-his kindred , and especially [he]35-walter looked on [the fair women there]236-the fair women there , and desired [them]236-the fair women there , and loved [them]236-the fair women there ; but lightly , as befalleth [young men]237-young men .

Now this was [the last country whereto [the Katherine]1550-the katherine was boun]238-the last country whereto the katherine was boun ; so there [they]230-they abode some ten months in daily chaffer , and in pleasuring [them]236-the fair women there in beholding all that there was of rare and goodly , and making merry with [the merchants]240-the merchants and [the towns - folk]241-the towns - folk , and [the country - folk beyond the gates]242-the country - folk beyond the gates , and [Walter]35-walter was grown as busy and gay as [a strong young man]243-a strong young man is like to be , and was as one who would fain be of some account amongst [[his]35-walter own folk]244-his own folk .

But at the end of this while , it befell on a day , as [he]35-walter was leaving [[his]35-walter hostel]245-his hostel for [his]35-walter booth in [the market]246-the market , and had the door in [his]35-walter hand , there stood before [him]35-walter [three mariners in the guise of [[his]35-walter own country]248-his own country]247-three mariners in the guise of his own country , and with [them]247-three mariners in the guise of his own country was one of [clerkly aspect , whom [he]35-walter knew at once for [[his]35-walter father]86-his father 's scrivener]249-clerkly aspect , whom he knew at once for his father 's scrivener , [Arnold Penstrong]41-arnold by name ; and when [Walter]35-walter saw [him]41-arnold [his]35-walter heart failed [him]35-walter and [he]35-walter cried out : " [Arnold]41-arnold , what tidings ? Is all well with [the folk at [Langton]35-walter]1581-the folk at langton ? "[35-walter]

Said [Arnold]41-arnold : " Evil tidings are come with [me]41-arnold ; matters are ill with [[thy]1581-the folk at langton folk]1582-thy folk ; for [I]41-arnold may not hide that [[thy]1581-the folk at langton father]1583-thy father , [Bartholomew Golden]36-bartholomew golden , is dead , [God]1584-god rest [his]86-his father soul . "[41-arnold]

At that word it was to [Walter]35-walter as if all that trouble which but now had sat so light upon [him]35-walter , was once again fresh and heavy , and that [his]35-walter past life of the last few months had never been ; and it was to [him]35-walter as if [he]35-walter saw [[his]35-walter father]86-his father lying dead on [his]86-his father bed , and heard [the folk]252-the folk lamenting about [the house]112-the house . [He]35-walter held [his]35-walter peace awhile , and then [he]35-walter said in a voice as of [an angry man]254-an angry man :

" What , [Arnold]41-arnold ! and did [he]86-his father die in [his]86-his father bed , or how ? for [he]86-his father was neither old nor ailing when [we]1585-we parted . "[35-walter]

Said [Arnold]41-arnold : " [Yea]1586-yea , in [his]86-his father bed [he]86-his father died : but first [he]86-his father was somewhat sword- bitten . "[35-walter]

" [Yea]1586-yea , and how ? "[35-walter] quoth [Walter]35-walter .

Said [Arnold]41-arnold : " When [thou]1587-thou [wert]1585-we gone , in a few days ' wearing , [[thy]1587-thou father]1583-thy father sent [[thy]1587-thou wife]1589-thy wife out of [[his]86-his father house]1590-his house back to [her]1589-thy wife kindred of [the Reddings]42-the reddings with no honour , and yet with no such shame as might have been , without blame to [us]1585-we of [those who knew the tale of [thee]1587-thou and [her]1589-thy wife]1591-those who knew the tale of thee and her ; which , God - a - mercy , will be pretty much [the whole of [the city]117-the city]1592-the whole of the city . "[41-arnold]

" Nevertheless , [the Reddings]42-the reddings took it amiss , and would have a mote with [us]1585-we [Goldings]43-goldings to talk of booting . By ill - luck [we]1585-we yea - said that for the saving of [the city]117-the city 's peace . But what betid ? [We]1585-we met in [[our]1585-we Gild - hall]1595-our gild - hall , and there befell the talk between [us]1585-we ; and in that talk certain words could not be hidden , though they were none too seemly nor too meek . And the said words once spoken drew forth the whetted steel ; and there then was the hewing and thrusting ! Two of [ours]1585-we were slain outright on the floor , and four of [theirs]42-the reddings , and [many]1596-many were hurt on either side . [Of these]1597-of these was [[thy]1587-thou father]1583-thy father , for as [thou]1587-thou mayst well deem , [he]1583-thy father was nought backward in the fray ; but despite [his]1583-thy father hurts , two in the side and one on the arm , [he]1583-thy father went home on [his]1583-thy father own feet , and [we]1585-we deemed that [we]1585-we had come to [our]1585-we above . But well - a- way ! it was an evil victory , whereas in ten days [he]1583-thy father died of [his]1583-thy father hurts . [God]44-god have [his]1583-thy father soul ! But now , [[my]35-walter master]1599-my master , [thou]1587-thou mayst well wot that [I]35-walter am not come to tell [thee]1599-my master this only , but moreover to bear the word of [the kindred]1600-the kindred , to wit that [thou]1587-thou come back with [me]35-walter straightway in the swift cutter which hath borne [me]35-walter and the tidings ; and [thou]1587-thou mayst look to it , that though [she]1587-thou be swift and light , [she]1587-thou is a keel full weatherly . "[35-walter]

Then said [Walter]35-walter : " This is a bidding of war . Come back will [I]35-walter , and [the Reddings]1601-the reddings shall wot of [my]35-walter coming . Are [ye]1599-my master all - boun ? "[35-walter]

" [Yea]1602-yea , "[41-arnold] said [Arnold]41-arnold , " [we]1603-we may up anchor this very day , or to - morrow morn at latest . But what aileth [thee]1599-my master , [master]1604-master , that [thou]1587-thou starest so wild over [my]41-arnold shoulder ? [I]41-arnold pray [thee]1599-my master take it not so much to heart ! Ever it is the wo nt of [fathers]1605-fathers to depart [this world]1606-this world before [[their]1605-fathers sons]1607-their sons . "[41-arnold]

But [Walter]35-walter 's visage from wrathful red had become pale , and [he]35-walter pointed up [street]255-street , and cried out : " Look ! dost [thou]35-walter see ? "[35-walter]

" See what , [master]1604-master ? "[41-arnold] quoth [Arnold]41-arnold : " what ! here cometh an ape in gay raiment ; belike [the beast of [some jongleur]1610-some jongleur]1609-the beast of some jongleur . Nay , by [God]44-god 's wounds ! ' tis [a man]229-a man , though [he]229-a man be exceeding mis - shapen like [a very devil]1612-a very devil . Yea and now there cometh [a pretty maid]1613-a pretty maid going as if [she]1613-a pretty maid were of [[his]229-a man meney]1614-his meney ; and lo ! here , [a most goodly and noble lady]1615-a most goodly and noble lady ! [Yea]1616-yea , [I]41-arnold see ; and doubtless [she]1615-a most goodly and noble lady owneth both the two , and is of the greatest of [the folk of [this fair city]1618-this fair city]1617-the folk of this fair city ; for on [the maiden]183-the maiden 's ankle [I]41-arnold saw an iron ring , which betokeneth thralldom amongst [these aliens]1620-these aliens . But this is strange ! for notest [thou]1621-thou not how [the folk in]1622-the folk in [the street]181-the street heed not this quaint show ; nay not even [the stately lady]184-the stately lady , though [she]184-the stately lady be as lovely as [a goddess of [the gentiles]1626-the gentiles]1625-a goddess of the gentiles , and beareth on [her]184-the stately lady gems that would buy [Langton]35-walter twice over ; surely they must be over- wo nt to strange and gallant sights . But now , [master]1604-master , but now ! "[41-arnold]

" Yea , what is it ? "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter .

" Why , [master]1604-master , [they]1620-these aliens should not yet be gone out of eye - shot , yet gone [they]1620-these aliens are . What is become of [them]1620-these aliens , are [they]1620-these aliens sunk into [the earth]1629-the earth ? "[35-walter]

" [Tush]45-tush , [man]1630-man ! "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter , looking not on [Arnold]41-arnold , but still staring down [the street]181-the street ; " [they]1620-these aliens have gone into [some house]1631-some house while thine eyes were turned from [them]1620-these aliens a moment . "[35-walter]

" Nay , [master]1604-master , nay , "[41-arnold] said [Arnold]41-arnold , " [mine]41-arnold eyes were not off them one instant of time . "[41-arnold]

" Well , "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter , somewhat snappishly , " [they]1620-these aliens are gone now , and what have [we]1633-we to do to heed such toys , [we]1633-we with all this grief and strife on [our]1633-we hands ? Now would [I]35-walter be alone to turn the matter of thine errand over in [my]35-walter mind . Meantime do [thou]1634-thou tell the shipmaster [Geoffrey]46-geoffrey and [[our]1633-we other folk]1635-our other folk of these tidings , and thereafter get [thee]1634-thou all ready ; and come hither to [me]35-walter before sunrise to - morrow , and [I]35-walter shall be ready for [my]35-walter part ; and so sail [we]1633-we back to [Langton]35-walter . "[35-walter]

Therewith [he]35-walter turned [him]35-walter back into [the house]112-the house , and [the others]258-the others went [their]258-the others ways ; but [Walter]35-walter sat alone in [[his]35-walter chamber]259-his chamber a long while , and pondered these things in [his]35-walter mind . And whiles [he]35-walter made up [his]35-walter mind that [he]35-walter would think no more of the vision of [those three]197-those three , but would fare back to [Langton]35-walter , and enter into the strife with [the Reddings]42-the reddings and quell [them]42-the reddings , or die else . But lo , when [he]35-walter was quite steady in this doom , and [his]35-walter heart was lightened thereby , [he]35-walter found that [he]35-walter thought no more of [the Reddings]42-the reddings and [their]42-the reddings strife , but as matters that were passed and done with , and that now [he]35-walter was thinking and devising if by any means [he]35-walter might find out in what [land dwelt]261-land dwelt [those three]197-those three . And then again [he]35-walter strove to put that from [him]35-walter , saying that what [he]35-walter had seen was but meet for [one brainsick]263-one brainsick , and [a dreamer of dreams]264-a dreamer of dreams . But furthermore [he]35-walter thought , Yea , and was [Arnold]41-arnold , who this last time had seen the images of those three , [a dreamer of waking dreams]265-a dreamer of waking dreams ? for [he]35-walter was nought wonted in such wise ; then thought [he]35-walter : At least [I]0-i am well content that [he]41-arnold spake to [me]0-i of [their]197-those three likeness , not [I]0-i to [him]41-arnold ; for so [I]0-i may tell that there was at least something before [my]0-i eyes which grew not out of [mine]0-i own brain . And yet again , why should [I]0-i follow [them]197-those three ; and what should [I]0-i get by it ; and indeed how shall [I]0-i set about it ?

Thus [he]35-walter turned the matter over and over ; and at last , seeing that if [he]35-walter grew no foolisher over it , [he]35-walter grew no wiser , [he]35-walter became weary thereof , and bestirred [him]35-walter , and saw to the trussing up of [his]35-walter goods , and made all ready for [his]35-walter departure , and so wore the day and slept at nightfall ; and at daybreak comes [Arnold]41-arnold to lead [him]35-walter to [their]197-those three keel , which hight [the Bartholomew]36-bartholomew golden . [He]35-walter tarried nought , and with few farewells went [aboard ship]190-aboard ship , and an hour after [they]197-those three were in [the open sea]267-the open sea with [the ship]155-the ship 's head turned toward [Langton]35-walter on [Holm]3-holm .

CHAPTER IV : STORM BEFALLS [THE BARTHOLOMEW]36-bartholomew golden , AND [SHE]155-the ship IS DRIVEN OFF [HER]155-the ship COURSE

Now swift sailed [the Bartholomew]36-bartholomew golden for four weeks toward [the north - west]269-the north - west with a fair wind , and all was well with [ship]131-ship and [crew]271-crew . Then the wind died out on even of a day , so that [the ship]155-the ship scarce made way at all , though [she]155-the ship rolled in a great swell of [the sea]89-the sea , so great , that it seemed to ridge all the main athwart . Moreover down in the west was a great bank of cloud huddled up in haze , whereas for twenty days past the sky had been clear , save for a few bright white clouds flying before the wind . Now [the shipmaster]274-the shipmaster , [a man right cunning in [his]274-the shipmaster craft]275-a man right cunning in his craft , looked long on [sea]276-sea and sky , and then turned and bade [the mariners]136-the mariners take in sail and be right heedful . And when [Walter]35-walter asked [him]274-the shipmaster what [he]274-the shipmaster looked for , and wherefore [he]274-the shipmaster spake not to [him]274-the shipmaster thereof , [he]274-the shipmaster said surlily : " Why should [I]274-the shipmaster tell [thee]35-walter what [any fool]1636-any fool can see without telling , to wit that there is weather to hand ? "[274-the shipmaster]

So [they]278-they abode what should befall , and [Walter]35-walter went to [[his]35-walter room]279-his room to sleep away the uneasy while , for the night was now fallen ; and [he]35-walter knew no more till [he]35-walter was waked up by great hubbub and clamour of [the shipmen]170-the shipmen , and the whipping of ropes , and thunder of flapping sails , and the tossing and weltering of [the ship]155-the ship withal . But , being [a very stout - hearted young man]282-a very stout - hearted young man , [he]35-walter lay still in [[his]35-walter room]279-his room , partly because [he]35-walter was [a landsman]284-a landsman , and had no mind to tumble about amongst [the shipmen]170-the shipmen and hinder [them]170-the shipmen ; and withal [he]35-walter said to [himself]35-walter : What matter whether [I]0-i go down to [the bottom of [the sea]89-the sea]286-the bottom of the sea , or come back to [Langton]35-walter , since either way [my]0-i life or [my]0-i death will take away from [me]0-i the fulfilment of desire ? Yet soothly if there hath been a shift of wind , that is not so ill ; for then shall [we]288-we be driven to [other lands]1554-other lands , and so at the least [our]288-we home - coming shall be delayed , and other tidings may hap amidst of [our]288-we tarrying . So let all be as it will .

So in a little while , in spite of [the ship]155-the ship 's wallowing and the tumult of the wind and waves , [he]35-walter fell asleep again , and woke no more till it was full daylight , and there was [the shipmaster]274-the shipmaster standing in the door of [[his]35-walter room]279-his room , the sea - water all streaming from [his]274-the shipmaster wet - weather raiment . [He]274-the shipmaster said to [Walter]35-walter : " [Young master]1637-young master , the sele of the day to [thee]35-walter ! For by good hap [we]288-we have gotten into another day . Now [I]274-the shipmaster shall tell [thee]35-walter that [we]288-we have striven to beat , so as not to be driven off [our]288-we course , but all would not avail , wherefore for these three hours [we]288-we have been running before the wind ; but , [fair sir]1638-fair sir , so big hath been [the sea]89-the sea that but for [[our]288-we ship]1640-our ship being of the stoutest , and [[our]288-we men]1641-our men all yare , [we]288-we had all grown exceeding wise concerning [the ground of the mid - main]1642-the ground of the mid - main . Praise be to [St. Nicholas]47-st. nicholas and [all Hallows]1643-all hallows ! for though [ye]35-walter shall presently look upon [a new sea]1644-a new sea , and maybe [a new land to boot]1645-a new land to boot , yet is that better than looking on the ugly things down below . "[274-the shipmaster]

" Is all well with [ship]131-ship and [crew]271-crew then ? "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter .

" Yea forsooth , "[274-the shipmaster] said [the shipmaster]274-the shipmaster ; " verily [the Bartholomew]36-bartholomew golden is [the darling of [Oak Woods]9-oak woods]1648-the darling of oak woods ; come up and look at it , how [she]297-she is dealing with wind and waves all free from fear . "[274-the shipmaster]

So [Walter]35-walter did on [his]35-walter foul - weather raiment , and went up on to [the quarter- deck]294-the quarter- deck , and there indeed was a change of days ; for [the sea]89-the sea was dark and tumbling mountain - high , and the white - horses were running down [the valleys thereof]296-the valleys thereof , and the clouds drave low over all , and bore a scud of rain along with them ; and though there was but a rag of sail on [her]297-she , [the ship]155-the ship flew before the wind , rolling a great wash of water from bulwark to [bulwark]10-bulwark .

[Walter]35-walter stood looking on it all awhile , holding on by a stay - rope , and saying to [himself]35-walter that it was well that [they]299-they were driving so fast toward new things .

Then [the shipmaster]274-the shipmaster came up to [him]35-walter and clapped [him]35-walter on the shoulder and said : " Well , [shipmate]1649-shipmate , cheer up ! and now come below again and eat some meat , and drink a cup with [me]274-the shipmaster . "[274-the shipmaster]

So [Walter]35-walter went down and ate and drank , and [his]35-walter heart was lighter than it had been since [he]35-walter had heard of [[his]35-walter father]86-his father 's death , and the feud awaiting [him]35-walter at [home]1557-home , which forsooth [he]35-walter had deemed would stay [his]35-walter wanderings a weary while , and therewithal [his]35-walter hopes . But now it seemed as if [he]35-walter needs must wander , would [he]35-walter , would [he]35-walter not ; and so it was that even this fed [his]35-walter hope ; so sore [his]35-walter heart clung to that desire of [his]35-walter to seek [home]1557-home to those three that seemed to call [him]35-walter unto [them]304-them .

CHAPTER V : NOW [THEY]305-they COME TO [A NEW LAND]11-a new land

Three days [they]305-they drave before the wind , and on the fourth the clouds lifted , the sun shone out and the offing was clear ; the wind had much abated , though it still blew a breeze , and was a head wind for sailing toward [the country of Langton]306-the country of langton . So then [the master]307-the master said that , since [they]305-they were bewildered , and the wind so ill to deal with , it were best to go still before the wind that [they]305-they might make [some land]308-some land and get knowledge of [their]305-they whereabouts from [the folk thereof]309-the folk thereof . Withal [he]307-the master said that [he]307-the master deemed [the land]101-the land not to be very far distant .

So did [they]305-they , and sailed on pleasantly enough , for the weather kept on mending , and the wind fell till it was but a light breeze , yet still foul for [Langton]35-walter .

So wore three days , and on the eve of the third , [the man from the topmast]311-the man from the topmast cried out that [he]311-the man from the topmast saw [land ahead]312-land ahead ; and so did [they]305-they all before the sun was quite set , though it were but a cloud no bigger than [a man]229-a man 's hand .

When night fell [they]305-they struck not sail , but went forth toward [the land]101-the land fair and softly ; for it was early summer , so that the nights were neither long nor dark .

But when it was broad daylight , [they]305-they opened [a land]315-a land , [a long shore of rocks and mountains]316-a long shore of rocks and mountains , and nought else that [they]305-they could see at first . Nevertheless as day wore and [they]305-they drew nigher , first [they]305-they saw how [the mountains]317-the mountains fell away from [the sea]89-the sea , and were behind [a long wall of sheer cliff]319-a long wall of sheer cliff ; and coming nigher yet , [they]305-they beheld a green plain going up after a little in green bents and slopes to the feet of the said cliff - wall .

[No city]320-no city nor haven did [they]305-they see there , not even when [they]305-they were far nigher to [the land]101-the land ; nevertheless , whereas [they]305-they hankered for the peace of [the green earth]322-the green earth after all the tossing and unrest of [the sea]89-the sea , and whereas also [they]305-they doubted not to find at the least good and fresh water , and belike other bait in [the plain under [the mountains]317-the mountains]324-the plain under the mountains , [they]305-they still sailed on not unmerrily ; so that by nightfall [they]305-they cast anchor in five - fathom water hard by [the shore]326-the shore .

Next morning [they]305-they found that [they]305-they were lying a little way off [the mouth of [a river]328-a river]327-the mouth of a river not right great ; so [they]305-they put out [[their]305-they boats]329-their boats and towed [the ship]155-the ship up into [the said river]331-the said river , and when [they]305-they had gone up [it]331-the said river for a mile or thereabouts [they]305-they found [the sea water]332-the sea water failed , for little was the ebb and flow of the tide on [that coast]333-that coast . Then was [the river]334-the river deep and clear , running between [smooth grassy land like [to meadows]336-to meadows]335-smooth grassy land like to meadows . Also on [their]305-they left board [they]305-they saw [presently three head of neat cattle]337-presently three head of neat cattle going , as if in a meadow of [a homestead in [[their]305-they own land]339-their own land]338-a homestead in their own land , and a few sheep ; and thereafter , about a bow - draught from [the river]334-the river , [they]305-they saw [a little house of wood and straw - thatch under a wooded mound , and with orchard trees about it]341-a little house of wood and straw - thatch under a wooded mound , and with orchard trees about it . [They]305-they wondered little thereat , for [they]305-they knew no cause why [that land]342-that land should not be builded , though it were in [the far outlands]343-the far outlands . However , [they]305-they drew [[their]305-they ship]344-their ship up to [the bank]345-the bank , thinking that [they]305-they would at least abide awhile and ask tidings and have some refreshing of [the green plain]346-the green plain , which was so lovely and pleasant .

But while [they]305-they were busied herein [they]305-they saw [a man]229-a man come out of [the house]112-the house , and down to [the river]334-the river to meet [them]305-they ; and [they]305-they soon saw that [he]229-a man was tall and old , long - hoary of hair and beard , and clad mostly in the skins of beasts .

[He]229-a man drew nigh without any fear or mistrust , and coming close to [them]305-they gave [them]305-they the sele of the day in a kindly and pleasant voice . [The shipmaster]274-the shipmaster greeted [him]229-a man in [his]229-a man turn , and said withal : " [Old man]1650-old man , art [thou]229-a man [the king of [this country]1652-this country]1651-the king of this country ? "[274-the shipmaster]

[The elder]127-the elder laughed ; " It hath had [none other]1653-none other a long while , "[127-the elder] said [he]127-the elder ; " and at least there is [no other son of [Adam]49-adam here to gainsay]1654-no other son of adam here to gainsay . "[127-the elder]

" [Thou]229-a man art alone here then ? "[307-the master] said [the master]307-the master .

" Yea , "[208-the old man] said [the old man]208-the old man ; ' save for the beasts of [the field]354-the field and the wood , and the creeping things , and fowl . Wherefore it is sweet to [me]0-i to hear [your]229-a man voices . "[307-the master]

Said [the master]307-the master : " Where be [the other houses of [the town]1656-the town]1655-the other houses of the town ? "[307-the master]

[The old man]208-the old man laughed . Said [he]208-the old man : " When [I]208-the old man said that [I]208-the old man was alone , [I]208-the old man meant that [I]208-the old man was alone in [the land]101-the land and not only alone in this stead . There is no house save this betwixt [the sea]89-the sea and [the dwellings of [the Bears]1660-the bears]1659-the dwellings of the bears , over [the cliff - wall yonder]1661-the cliff - wall yonder , yea and a long way over it . "[208-the old man]

" Yea , "[274-the shipmaster] quoth [the shipmaster]274-the shipmaster grinning , " and be [the bears of [[thy]229-a man country]1663-thy country]1662-the bears of thy country so manlike , that [they]1662-the bears of thy country dwell in [builded houses]1664-builded houses ? "[274-the shipmaster]

[The old man]208-the old man shook [his]208-the old man head . " [Sir]1665-sir , "[208-the old man] said [he]208-the old man , " as to [their]1662-the bears of thy country bodily fashion , it is altogether manlike , save that [they]1662-the bears of thy country be one and all higher and bigger than most . For [they]1662-the bears of thy country be bears only in name ; [they]1662-the bears of thy country be [a nation of half wild men]1666-a nation of half wild men ; for [I]208-the old man have been told by [them]1662-the bears of thy country that there be many more than [that tribe whose folk]1667-that tribe whose folk [I]208-the old man have seen , and that [they]1662-the bears of thy country spread wide about behind these mountains from east to west . Now , [sir]1665-sir , as to [their]1662-the bears of thy country souls and understandings [I]208-the old man warrant [them]1662-the bears of thy country not ; for [miscreants]1669-miscreants [they]1662-the bears of thy country be , trowing neither in [God]44-god nor [[his]1670-his hallows]1671-his hallows . "[208-the old man]

Said [the master]307-the master : " Trow [they]1662-the bears of thy country in [Mahound]12-mahound then ? "[307-the master]

" Nay , "[127-the elder] said [the elder]127-the elder , " [I]127-the elder wot not for sure that [they]1662-the bears of thy country have so much as [a false God]1672-a false god ; though [I]127-the elder have it from [them]1662-the bears of thy country that [they]1662-the bears of thy country worship [a certain woman with mickle worship]1673-a certain woman with mickle worship . "[127-the elder]

Then spake [Walter]35-walter : " [Yea]1674-yea , [good sir]1675-good sir , and how knowest [thou]35-walter that ? dost [thou]35-walter deal with [them]1662-the bears of thy country at all ? "[35-walter]

Said [the old man]208-the old man : " Whiles [some of [that folk]1677-that folk]1676-some of that folk come hither and have of [me]208-the old man what [I]208-the old man can spare ; a calf or two , or a half - dozen of lambs or hoggets ; or a skin of wine or cyder of [mine]208-the old man own making : and [they]1676-some of that folk give [me]208-the old man in return such things as [I]208-the old man can use , as skins of hart and bear and other peltries ; for now [I]208-the old man am old , [I]208-the old man can but little of the hunting hereabout . Whiles , also , [they]1676-some of that folk bring little lumps of pure copper , and would give [me]208-the old man gold also , but it is of little use in [this lonely land]1678-this lonely land . Sooth to say , to [me]208-the old man [they]1676-some of that folk are not masterful or rough - handed ; but glad am [I]208-the old man that [they]1676-some of that folk have been here but of late , and are not like to come again this while ; for terrible [they]1676-some of that folk are of aspect , and whereas [ye]1679-ye be [aliens]137-aliens , belike [they]1676-some of that folk would not hold [their]1676-some of that folk hands from off [you]1679-ye ; and moreover [ye]1679-ye have weapons and other matters which [they]1676-some of that folk would covet sorely . "[208-the old man]

Quoth [the master]307-the master : " Since [thou]1681-thou dealest with [these wild men]1682-these wild men , will [ye]1679-ye not deal with [us]1683-we in chaffer ? For whereas [we]1683-we are come from long travel , [we]1683-we hanker after fresh victual , and here aboard are many things which were for thine avail . "[307-the master]

Said [the old man]208-the old man : " All that [I]208-the old man have is [yours]1679-ye , so that [ye]1679-ye do but leave [me]208-the old man enough till [my]208-the old man next ingathering : of wine and cyder , such as it is , [I]208-the old man have plenty for [your]1679-ye service ; [ye]1679-ye may drink it till it is all gone , if [ye]1679-ye will : a little corn and meal [I]208-the old man have , but not much ; yet are [ye]1679-ye welcome thereto , since the standing corn in [[my]208-the old man garth]1684-my garth is done blossoming , and [I]208-the old man have other meat . Cheeses have [I]208-the old man and dried fish ; take what [ye]1679-ye will thereof . But as to [my]208-the old man neat and sheep , if [ye]1679-ye have sore need of any , and will have them , [I]208-the old man may not say [you]1679-ye nay : but [I]208-the old man pray [you]1679-ye if [ye]1679-ye may do without [them]1685-them , not to take [my]208-the old man milch - beasts or [[their]1685-them engenderers]1686-their engenderers ; for , as [ye]1679-ye have heard [me]208-the old man say , [the Bear - folk]1687-the bear - folk have been here but of late , and [they]1687-the bear - folk have had of [me]208-the old man all [I]208-the old man might spare : but now let [me]208-the old man tell [you]1679-ye , if [ye]1679-ye long after flesh - meat , that there is venison of hart and hind , yea , and of buck and doe , to be had on [this plain]1688-this plain , and about [the little woods at the feet of the rock - wall yonder]1689-the little woods at the feet of the rock - wall yonder : neither are they exceeding wild ; for since [I]208-the old man may not take them , [I]208-the old man scare [them]1687-the bear - folk not , and [no other man]1690-no other man do [they]1687-the bear - folk see to hurt [them]1687-the bear - folk ; for [the Bear- folk]1691-the bear- folk come straight to [[my]208-the old man house]1562-my house , and fare straight [home]1557-home thence . But [I]208-the old man will lead [you]1679-ye the nighest way to where the venison is easiest to be gotten . As to the wares in [[your]1679-ye ship]1694-your ship , if [ye]1679-ye will give [me]208-the old man aught [I]208-the old man will take it with a good will ; and chiefly if [ye]1679-ye have a fair knife or two and a roll of linen cloth , that were a good refreshment to [me]208-the old man . But in any case what [I]208-the old man have to give is free to [you]1679-ye and welcome . "[208-the old man]

[The shipmaster]274-the shipmaster laughed : " [Friend]1695-friend , "[274-the shipmaster] said [he]274-the shipmaster , " [we]1696-we can [thee]1679-ye mickle thanks for all that [thou]1679-ye biddest [us]1696-we . And wot well that [we]1696-we be [no lifters]1697-no lifters or sea - thieves to take [thy]1679-ye livelihood from [thee]1679-ye . So to - morrow , if [thou]1679-ye wilt , [we]1696-we will go with [thee]1679-ye and upraise the hunt , and meanwhile [we]1696-we will come aland , and walk on the green grass , and water [[our]1696-we ship]1640-our ship with [thy]1679-ye good fresh water . "[274-the shipmaster]

So [the old carle]365-the old carle went back to [[his]365-the old carle house]1590-his house to make [them]367-they ready what cheer [he]365-the old carle might , and [the shipmen , who were twenty and one , all told]368-the shipmen , who were twenty and one , all told , what with [the mariners]136-the mariners and [Arnold]41-arnold and [[Walter]35-walter 's servants]370-walter 's servants , went ashore , [all but two who watched the ship and abode]371-all but two who watched the ship and abode [their]371-all but two who watched the ship and abode turn . [They]367-they went well - weaponed , for both [the master]307-the master and [Walter]35-walter deemed wariness wisdom , lest all might not be so good as it seemed . [They]367-they took of [their]367-they sail - cloths ashore and tilted [them]367-they in on [the meadow]373-the meadow betwixt [the house]112-the house and [the ship]155-the ship , and [the carle]376-the carle brought [them]367-they what [he]376-the carle had for [their]367-they avail , of fresh fruits , and cheeses , and milk , and wine , and cyder , and honey , and there [they]367-they feasted nowise ill , and were right fain .

CHAPTER VI : [THE OLD MAN]208-the old man TELLS [WALTER]35-walter OF [HIMSELF]35-walter . [WALTER]35-walter SEES A SHARD IN [THE CLIFF - WALL]378-the cliff - wall

But when [they]367-they had done [their]367-they meat and drink [the master]307-the master and [the shipmen]170-the shipmen went about the watering of [the ship]155-the ship , and [the others]258-the others strayed off along [the meadow]373-the meadow , so that presently [Walter]35-walter was left alone with [the carle]376-the carle , and fell to speech with [him]376-the carle and said : " [Father]1546-father , [meseemeth]1700-thou [thou]1700-thou shouldest have some strange tale to tell , and as yet [we]367-they have asked [thee]1700-thou of nought save meat for [our]367-they bellies : now if [I]376-the carle ask [thee]1700-thou concerning [thy]1700-thou life , and how [thou]1700-thou camest hither , and abided here , wilt [thou]1700-thou tell [me]376-the carle aught ? "[376-the carle]

[The old man]208-the old man smiled on [him]35-walter and said : " [Son]1556-son , [my]208-the old man tale were long to tell ; and mayhappen concerning much thereof [my]208-the old man memory should fail [me]208-the old man ; and withal there is grief therein , which [I]208-the old man were loth to awaken : nevertheless if [thou]1700-thou ask , [I]208-the old man will answer as [I]208-the old man may , and in any case will tell [thee]1556-son nought save the truth . "[208-the old man]

Said [Walter]35-walter : " Well then , hast [thou]1700-thou been long here ? "[35-walter]

" [Yea]1702-yea , "[376-the carle] said [the carle]376-the carle , ' since [I]0-i was [a young man]87-a young man , and [a stalwarth knight]388-a stalwarth knight . "[376-the carle]

Said [Walter]35-walter : " [This house]1703-this house , didst [thou]1700-thou build [it]1703-this house , and raise [these garths]1704-these garths , and plant orchard and vineyard , and gather together the neat and the sheep , or did some other do all this for [thee]1556-son ? "[35-walter]

Said [the carle]376-the carle : " [I]376-the carle did none of all this ; there was one here before [me]376-the carle , and [I]376-the carle entered into [his]0-i inheritance , as though this were [a lordly manor]1705-a lordly manor , with [a fair castle thereon]1706-a fair castle thereon , and [all well stocked and plenished]1707-all well stocked and plenished . "[376-the carle]

Said [Walter]35-walter : " Didst [thou]1700-thou find [[thy]1700-thou foregoer]1708-thy foregoer alive here ? "[35-walter]

" [Yea]1709-yea , "[127-the elder] said [the elder]127-the elder , " yet [he]0-i lived but for a little while after [I]127-the elder came to [him]0-i . "[127-the elder]

[He]127-the elder was silent a while , and then [he]127-the elder said : " [I]127-the elder slew [him]0-i : even so would [he]0-i have it , though [I]127-the elder bade [him]0-i a better lot . "[127-the elder]

Said [Walter]35-walter : " Didst [thou]1700-thou come hither of [thine]1700-thou own will ? "[35-walter]

" Mayhappen , "[376-the carle] said [the carle]376-the carle ; " who knoweth ? Now have [I]376-the carle no will to do either this or that . It is wo nt that maketh [me]376-the carle do , or refrain . "[376-the carle]

Said [Walter]35-walter : " Tell [me]35-walter this ; why didst [thou]1700-thou slay [the man]1710-the man ? did [he]1710-the man any scathe to [thee]1700-thou ? "[35-walter]

Said [the elder]127-the elder : " When [I]127-the elder slew [him]1710-the man , [I]127-the elder deemed that [he]1710-the man was doing [me]127-the elder all scathe : but now [I]127-the elder know that it was not so . Thus it was : [I]127-the elder would needs go where [he]1710-the man had been before , and [he]1710-the man stood in the path against [me]127-the elder ; and [I]127-the elder overthrew [him]1710-the man , and went on the way [I]127-the elder would . "[127-the elder]

" What came thereof ? "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter .

" Evil came of it , "[376-the carle] said [the carle]376-the carle .

Then was [Walter]35-walter silent a while , and [the old man]208-the old man spake nothing ; but there came a smile in [his]208-the old man face that was both sly and somewhat sad . [Walter]35-walter looked on [him]208-the old man and said : " Was it from hence that [thou]1711-thou wouldst go [that road]1712-that road ? "[35-walter]

" Yea , "[376-the carle] said [the carle]376-the carle .

Said [Walter]35-walter : " And now wilt [thou]1711-thou tell [me]35-walter what [that road]1712-that road was ; whither it went and whereto it led , that [thou]1711-thou must needs wend it , though [thy]1711-thou first stride were over [a dead man]1714-a dead man ? "[35-walter]

" [I]376-the carle will not tell [thee]35-walter , "[376-the carle] said [the carle]376-the carle .

Then [they]397-they held [their]397-they peace , both of [them]397-they , and thereafter got on to other talk of no import .

So wore the day till night came ; and [they]397-they slept safely , and on the morrow after [they]397-they had broken [their]397-they fast , the more part of [them]397-they set off with [the carle]376-the carle to the hunting , and [they]397-they went , all of [them]397-they , a three hours ' faring towards the foot of [the cliffs]399-the cliffs , which was all grown over with coppice , hazel and thorn , with here and there a big oak or ash - tree ; there it was , said [the old man , where the venison was most and best]400-the old man , where the venison was most and best .

Of [their]397-they hunting need nought be said , saving that when [the carle]376-the carle had put [them]397-they on the track of the deer and shown [them]397-they what to do , [he]376-the carle came back again with [Walter]35-walter , who had no great lust for the hunting , and sorely longed to have some more talk with [the said carle]402-the said carle . [He]376-the carle for [his]376-the carle part seemed nought loth thereto , and so led [Walter]35-walter to [a mound or hillock amidst the clear of [the plain]404-the plain]403-a mound or hillock amidst the clear of the plain , whence all was to be seen save where the wood covered [it]405-it ; but just before where [they]397-they now lay down there was no wood , save low bushes , betwixt [them]397-they and the rock - wall ; and [Walter]35-walter noted that whereas otherwhere , save in one place whereto [their]397-they eyes were turned , [the cliffs]399-the cliffs seemed wellnigh or quite sheer , or indeed in some places beetling over , in that said place [they]397-they fell away from each other on either side ; and before this sinking was a slope or scree , that went gently up toward the sinking of the wall . [Walter]35-walter looked long and earnestly at [this place]407-this place , and spake nought , till [the carle]376-the carle said : " What ! [thou]376-the carle hast found something before [thee]35-walter to look on . What is it then ? "[376-the carle]

Quoth [Walter]35-walter : " [Some]1715-some would say that where [yonder slopes]1716-yonder slopes run together up towards that sinking in the cliff - wall there will be [a pass into [the country beyond]1718-the country beyond]1717-a pass into the country beyond . "[35-walter]

[The carle]376-the carle smiled and said : " [Yea]1719-yea , [son]1556-son ; nor , so saying , would [they]397-they err ; for that is [the pass into [the Bear - country]1722-the bear - country]1721-the pass into the bear - country , whereby [those huge men]1723-those huge men come down to chaffer with [me]376-the carle . "[376-the carle]

" Yea , "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter ; and therewith [he]35-walter turned [him]35-walter a little , and scanned the rock - wall , and saw how a few miles from [that pass]410-that pass [it]411-it turned somewhat sharply toward [the sea]89-the sea , narrowing [the plain]404-the plain much there , till it made a bight , the face whereof looked wellnigh north , instead of west , as did the more part of the wall . And in the midst of [that northern - looking bight]414-that northern - looking bight was a dark place which seemed to [Walter]35-walter like a downright shard in [the cliff]415-the cliff . For the face of the wall was of a bleak grey , and it was but little furrowed .

So then [Walter]35-walter spake : " [Lo]50-lo , [old friend]1724-old friend , there yonder is again [a place that [meseemeth]1725-a place that meseemeth is a pass is [a pass]1726-a pass]1725-a place that meseemeth is a pass ; whereunto doth that one lead ? "[35-walter] And [he]35-walter pointed to it : but [the old man]208-the old man did not follow the pointing of [his]208-the old man finger , but , looking down on the ground , answered confusedly , and said :

" Maybe : [I]208-the old man wot not . [I]208-the old man deem that it also leadeth into [the Bear - country]1722-the bear - country by [a roundabout road]1728-a roundabout road . It leadeth into [the far land]1729-the far land . "[208-the old man]

[Walter]35-walter answered nought : for a strange thought had come uppermost in [his]35-walter mind , that [the carle]376-the carle knew far more than [he]35-walter would say of [that pass]410-that pass , and that [he]35-walter [himself]35-walter might be led thereby to find the wondrous three . [He]35-walter caught [his]35-walter breath hardly , and [his]35-walter heart knocked against [his]35-walter ribs ; but [he]35-walter refrained from speaking for a long while ; but at last [he]35-walter spake in a sharp hard voice , which [he]35-walter scarce knew for [his]35-walter own : " [Father]51-father , tell [me]35-walter , [I]35-walter adjure [thee]35-walter by [God]44-god and [All - hallows]1730-all - hallows , was it through yonder shard that [the road]1731-the road lay , when [thou]35-walter must needs make [thy]35-walter first stride over [a dead man]1714-a dead man ? "[35-walter]

[The old man]208-the old man spake not a while , then [he]208-the old man raised [his]208-the old man head , and looked [Walter]35-walter full in the eyes , and said in a steady voice : " NO , IT WAS NOT . "[208-the old man] Thereafter [they]420-they sat looking at [each other]421-each other a while ; but at last [Walter]35-walter turned [his]35-walter eyes away , but knew not what [they]420-they beheld nor where [he]35-walter was , but [he]35-walter was as [one in a swoon]422-one in a swoon . For [he]35-walter knew full well that [the carle]376-the carle had lied to [him]35-walter , and that [he]35-walter might as well have said aye as no , and told [him]35-walter , that it verily was by that same shard that [he]35-walter had stridden over [a dead man]1714-a dead man . Nevertheless [he]35-walter made as little semblance thereof as [he]35-walter might , and presently came to [himself]35-walter , and fell to talking of other matters , that had nought to do with the adventures of [the land]101-the land . But after a while [he]35-walter spake suddenly , and said : " [[My]35-walter master]1599-my master , [I]35-walter was thinking of a thing . "[35-walter]

" [Yea]1734-yea , of what ? "[376-the carle] said [the carle]376-the carle .

" Of this , "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter ; " that here in [this land]1735-this land be strange adventures toward , and that if [we]1736-we , and [I]35-walter in especial , were to turn [our]1736-we backs on [them]1737-them , and go [home]1557-home with nothing done , it were pity of [our]1736-we lives : for all will be dull and deedless [there]1739-there . [I]35-walter was deeming it were good if [we]1736-we tried the adventure . "[35-walter]

" What adventure ? "[208-the old man] said [the old man]208-the old man , rising up on [his]208-the old man elbow and staring sternly on [him]35-walter .

Said [Walter]35-walter : " The wending yonder pass to the eastward , whereby [the huge men]1740-the huge men come to [thee]35-walter from out of [the Bear - country]1722-the bear - country ; that [we]1736-we might see what should come thereof . "[35-walter]

[The carle]376-the carle leaned back again , and smiled and shook [his]376-the carle head , and spake : " That adventure were speedily proven : death would come of it , [[my]376-the carle son]1565-my son . "[376-the carle]

" [Yea]1743-yea , and how ? "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter .

[The carle]376-the carle said : " [The big men]1744-the big men would take [thee]35-walter , and offer [thee]35-walter up as a blood - offering to [that woman , who is [their]1744-the big men Mawmet]1745-that woman , who is their mawmet . And if [ye]35-walter go all , then shall [they]1744-the big men do the like with all of [you]35-walter . "[376-the carle]

Said [Walter]35-walter : " Is that sure ? "[35-walter]

" Dead sure , "[376-the carle] said [the carle]376-the carle .

" How knowest [thou]1746-thou this ? "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter .

" [I]376-the carle have been [there]1739-there [myself]376-the carle , "[376-the carle] said [the carle]376-the carle .

" [Yea]1748-yea , "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter , " but [thou]1746-thou camest away whole . "[35-walter]

" Art [thou]1746-thou sure thereof ? "[376-the carle] said [the carle]376-the carle .

" [Thou]1746-thou art alive yet , [old man]1650-old man , "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter , " for [I]35-walter have seen [thee]1746-thou eat [thy]1746-thou meat , which ghosts use not to do . "[35-walter] And [he]35-walter laughed .

But [the old man]208-the old man answered soberly : " If [I]208-the old man escaped , it was by this , that [another woman]1750-another woman saved [me]208-the old man , and not often shall that befall . Nor wholly was [I]208-the old man saved ; [my]208-the old man body escaped forsooth . But where is [my]208-the old man soul ? Where is [my]208-the old man heart , and [my]208-the old man life ? [Young man]1751-young man , [I]208-the old man rede [thee]1751-young man , try no such adventure ; but go [home]1557-home to [thy]1751-young man kindred if [thou]1751-young man canst . Moreover , wouldst [thou]1751-young man fare alone ? [The others]258-the others shall hinder [thee]1751-young man . "[208-the old man]

Said [Walter]35-walter : " [I]35-walter am [the master]307-the master ; [they]258-the others shall do as [I]35-walter bid [them]258-the others : besides , [they]258-the others will be well pleased to share [my]35-walter goods amongst [them]258-the others if [I]35-walter give [them]258-the others a writing to clear [them]258-the others of all charges which might be brought against [them]258-the others . "[35-walter]

" [[My]376-the carle son]1565-my son ! [[my]376-the carle son]1565-my son ! "[376-the carle] said [the carle]376-the carle , " [I]376-the carle pray [thee]1565-my son go not to [thy]1565-my son death ! "[376-the carle]

[Walter]35-walter heard [him]376-the carle silently , but as if [he]35-walter were persuaded to refrain ; and then [the old man]208-the old man fell to , and told [him]35-walter much concerning [this Bear - folk]436-this bear - folk and [their]436-this bear - folk customs , speaking very freely of [them]436-this bear - folk ; but [Walter]35-walter 's ears were scarce open to this talk : whereas [he]35-walter deemed that [he]35-walter should have nought to do with [those wild men]437-those wild men ; and [he]35-walter durst not ask again concerning [the country whereto led [the pass]439-the pass on the northward]438-the country whereto led the pass on the northward .

CHAPTER VII : [WALTER]35-walter COMES TO [THE SHARD]52-the shard IN [THE ROCK - WALL]440-the rock - wall

As [they]441-they were in converse thus , [they]441-they heard [the hunters]442-the hunters blowing on [their]442-the hunters horns all together ; whereon [the old man]208-the old man arose , and said : " [I]208-the old man deem by the blowing that the hunt will be over and done , and that [they]442-the hunters be blowing on [[their]442-the hunters fellows who have gone scatter - meal about [the wood]1758-the wood]1757-their fellows who have gone scatter - meal about the wood . It is now some five hours after noon , and [[thy]208-the old man men]1759-thy men will be getting back with [their]442-the hunters venison , and will be fainest of the victuals [they]442-the hunters have caught ; therefore will [I]208-the old man hasten on before , and get ready fire and water and other matters for the cooking . Wilt [thou]208-the old man come with [me]208-the old man , [young master]1637-young master , or abide [[thy]208-the old man men]1759-thy men here ? "[208-the old man]

[Walter]35-walter said lightly : " [I]35-walter will rest and abide [them]1759-thy men here ; since [I]35-walter can not fail to see [them]1759-thy men hence as [they]1759-thy men go on [their]1759-thy men ways to [thine house]1762-thine house . And it may be well that [I]35-walter be at hand to command [them]1759-thy men and forbid , and put some order amongst [them]1759-thy men , for rough playmates [they]1759-thy men be , some of [them]1759-thy men , and now all heated with the hunting and the joy of [the green earth]322-the green earth . "[35-walter] Thus [he]35-walter spoke , as if nought were toward save supper and bed ; but inwardly hope and fear were contending in [him]35-walter , and again [his]35-walter heart beat so hard , that [he]35-walter deemed that [the carle]376-the carle must surely hear it . But [the old man]208-the old man took [him]35-walter but according to [his]208-the old man outward seeming , and nodded [his]208-the old man head , and went away quietly toward [[his]208-the old man house]1590-his house .

When [he]208-the old man had been gone a little , [Walter]35-walter rose up heedfully ; [he]35-walter had with [him]35-walter a scrip wherein was some cheese and hard - fish , and a little flasket of wine ; a short bow [he]35-walter had with [him]35-walter , and a quiver of arrows ; and [he]35-walter was girt with a strong and good sword , and a wood - knife withal . [He]35-walter looked to all this gear that it was nought amiss , and then speedily went down off [the mound]447-the mound , and when [he]35-walter was come down , [he]35-walter found that it covered [him]35-walter from [men coming out of the wood]448-men coming out of the wood , if [he]35-walter went straight thence to that shard of the rock - wall where was the pass that led southward .

Now it is no nay that thitherward [he]35-walter turned , and went wisely , lest [the carle]376-the carle should make a backward cast , and see [him]35-walter , or lest [any straggler of [[his]35-walter own folk]244-his own folk]450-any straggler of his own folk might happen upon [him]35-walter .

For to say sooth , [he]35-walter deemed that did [they]244-his own folk wind [him]35-walter , [they]244-his own folk would be like to let [him]35-walter of [his]35-walter journey . [He]35-walter had noted the bearings of [the cliffs]399-the cliffs nigh the shard , and whereas [he]35-walter could see [their]244-his own folk heads everywhere except from the depths of the thicket , [he]35-walter was not like to go astray .

[He]35-walter had made no great way ere [he]35-walter heard the horns blowing all together again in one place , and looking thitherward through the leafy boughs for [he]35-walter was now amidst of a thicket [he]35-walter saw [[his]35-walter men]453-his men thronging the mound , and had no doubt therefore that [they]453-his men were blowing on [him]35-walter ; but being well under cover [he]35-walter heeded it nought , and lying still a little , saw [them]453-his men go down off the mound and go all of [them]453-his men toward [[the carle]376-the carle 's house]455-the carle 's house , still blowing as [they]453-his men went , but not faring scatter - meal . Wherefore it was clear that [they]453-his men were nought troubled about [him]35-walter .

So [he]35-walter went on [his]35-walter way to the shard ; and there is nothing to say of [his]35-walter journey till [he]35-walter got before [it]456-it with the last of the clear day , and entered [it]456-it straightway . [It]456-it was in sooth a downright breach or cleft in the rock- wall , and there was no hill or bent leading up to [it]456-it , nothing but a tumble of stones before it , which was somewhat uneasy going , yet needed nought but labour to overcome it , and when [he]35-walter had got over this , and was in [the very pass]457-the very pass [itself]457-the very pass , [he]35-walter found it no ill going : forsooth at first it was little worse than [a rough road betwixt two great stony slopes]458-a rough road betwixt two great stony slopes , though a little trickle of water ran down amidst of [it]458-a rough road betwixt two great stony slopes . So , though it was so nigh nightfall , yet [Walter]35-walter pressed on , yea , and long after the very night was come . For the moon rose wide and bright a little after nightfall . But at last [he]35-walter had gone so long , and was so wearied , that [he]35-walter deemed it nought but wisdom to rest [him]35-walter , and so lay down on a piece of greensward betwixt the stones , when [he]35-walter had eaten a morsel out of [his]35-walter satchel , and drunk of the water out of [the stream]459-the stream . There as [he]35-walter lay , if [he]35-walter had any doubt of peril , [his]35-walter weariness soon made it all one to [him]35-walter , for presently [he]35-walter was sleeping as soundly as [any man in [Langton]35-walter on [Holm]3-holm]460-any man in langton on holm .

CHAPTER VIII : [WALTER WENDS THE WASTE]53-walter

Day was yet young when [he]35-walter awoke : [he]35-walter leapt to [his]35-walter feet , and went down to [the stream]459-the stream and drank of its waters , and washed the night off [him]35-walter in a pool thereof , and then set forth on [his]35-walter way again . When [he]35-walter had gone some three hours , [the road]1731-the road , which had been going up all the way , but somewhat gently , grew steeper , and the bent on either side lowered , and lowered , till it sank at last altogether , and then was [he]35-walter on [a rough mountain - neck]463-a rough mountain - neck with little grass , and no water ; save that now and again was a soft place with a flow amidst of it , and such places [he]35-walter must needs fetch a compass about , lest [he]35-walter be mired . [He]35-walter gave [himself]35-walter but little rest , eating what [he]35-walter needs must as [he]35-walter went . The day was bright and calm , so that the sun was never hidden , and [he]35-walter steered by [it]464-it [due south]465-due south . All that day [he]35-walter went , and found no more change in that huge neck , save that whiles it was more and whiles less steep . A little before nightfall [he]35-walter happened on [a shallow pool some twenty yards over]466-a shallow pool some twenty yards over ; and [he]35-walter deemed it good to rest there , since there was water for [his]35-walter avail , though [he]35-walter might have made somewhat more out of the tail end of the day .

When dawn came again [he]35-walter awoke and arose , nor spent much time over [his]35-walter breakfast ; but pressed on all [he]35-walter might ; and now [he]35-walter said to [himself]35-walter , that whatsoever other peril were athwart [his]35-walter way , [he]35-walter was out of the danger of the chase of [[his]35-walter own folk]244-his own folk .

All this while [he]35-walter had seen no four - footed beast , save now and again a hill - fox , and once some outlandish kind of hare ; and of fowl but very few : a crow or two , a long - winged hawk , and twice an eagle high up aloft .

Again , the third night , [he]35-walter slept in [the stony wilderness]468-the stony wilderness , which still led [him]35-walter up and up . Only toward the end of the day , himseemed that it had been less steep for a long while : otherwise nought was changed , on all sides it was nought but [the endless neck]469-the endless neck , wherefrom nought could be seen , but some other part of [itself]469-the endless neck . This fourth night withal [he]35-walter found no water whereby [he]35-walter might rest , so that [he]35-walter awoke parched , and longing to drink just when the dawn was at its coldest .

But on the fifth morrow [the ground]470-the ground rose but little , and at last , when [he]35-walter had been going wearily a long while , and now , hard on noontide , [his]35-walter thirst grieved [him]35-walter sorely , [he]35-walter came on a spring welling out from under [a high rock]471-a high rock , the water wherefrom trickled feebly away . So eager was [he]35-walter to drink , that at first [he]35-walter heeded nought else ; but when [his]35-walter thirst was fully quenched [his]35-walter eyes caught sight of the stream which flowed from [the well]472-the well , and [he]35-walter gave a shout , for lo ! it was running south . Wherefore it was with a merry heart that [he]35-walter went on , and as [he]35-walter went , came on more streams , all running south or thereabouts . [He]35-walter hastened on all [he]35-walter might , but in despite of all the speed [he]35-walter made , and that [he]35-walter felt [the land]101-the land now going down southward , night overtook [him]35-walter in [that same wilderness]474-that same wilderness . Yet when [he]35-walter stayed at last for sheer weariness , [he]35-walter lay down in what [he]35-walter deemed by the moonlight to be [a shallow valley]475-a shallow valley , with [a ridge at the southern end thereof]476-a ridge at the southern end thereof .

[He]35-walter slept long , and when [he]35-walter awoke the sun was high in the heavens , and never was brighter or clearer morning on [the earth]1629-the earth than was that . [He]35-walter arose and ate of what little was yet left [him]35-walter , and drank of the water of a stream which [he]35-walter had followed the evening before , and beside which [he]35-walter had laid [him]35-walter down ; and then set forth again with no great hope to come on new tidings that day .
