But yet when [he]35-walter was fairly afoot , himseemed that there was something new in the air which [he]35-walter breathed , that was soft and bore sweet scents home to [him]35-walter ; whereas heretofore , and that especially for the last three or four days , it had been harsh and void , like the face of [the desert]478-the desert itself .

So on [he]35-walter went , and presently was mounting [the ridge aforesaid]479-the ridge aforesaid , and , as oft happens when one climbs [a steep place]480-a steep place , [he]35-walter kept [his]35-walter eyes on the ground , till [he]35-walter felt [he]35-walter was on the top of [the ridge]481-the ridge . Then [he]35-walter stopped to take breath , and raised [his]35-walter head and looked , and lo ! [he]35-walter was verily on [the brow of [the great mountain - neck]483-the great mountain - neck]482-the brow of the great mountain - neck , and down below [him]35-walter was the hanging of [the great hill - slopes]484-the great hill - slopes , which fell down , not slowly , as those [he]35-walter had been those days a - mounting , but speedily enough , though with little of broken places or sheer cliffs . But beyond [this last of the desert]485-this last of the desert there was before [him]35-walter a lovely land of [wooded hills , green plains , and little valleys , stretching out far and wide]486-wooded hills , green plains , and little valleys , stretching out far and wide , till it ended at last in [great blue mountains and white snowy peaks beyond [them]487-great blue mountains and white snowy peaks beyond them]487-great blue mountains and white snowy peaks beyond them .

Then for very surprise of joy [his]35-walter spirit wavered , and [he]35-walter felt faint and dizzy , so that [he]35-walter was fain to sit down a while and cover [his]35-walter face with [his]35-walter hands . Presently [he]35-walter came to [his]35-walter sober mind again , and stood up and looked forth keenly , and saw no sign of any dwelling of [man]1630-man . But [he]35-walter said to [himself]35-walter that that might well be because [the good and well - grassed land]489-the good and well - grassed land was still so far off , and that [he]35-walter might yet look to find [men]165-men and [[their]165-men dwellings]491-their dwellings when [he]35-walter had left [the mountain wilderness]492-the mountain wilderness quite behind [him]35-walter : So therewith [he]35-walter fell to going [his]35-walter ways down [the mountain]493-the mountain , and lost little time therein , whereas [he]35-walter now had [his]35-walter livelihood to look to .

CHAPTER IX : [WALTER]53-walter HAPPENETH ON THE FIRST OF [THOSE THREE CREATURES]494-those three creatures

What with one thing , what with another , as [his]35-walter having to turn out of [his]35-walter way for sheer rocks , or for slopes so steep that [he]35-walter might not try the peril of them , and again for bogs impassable , [he]35-walter was fully three days more before [he]35-walter had quite come out of the stony waste , and by that time , though [he]35-walter had never lacked water , [his]35-walter scanty victual was quite done , for all [his]35-walter careful husbandry thereof . But this troubled [him]35-walter little , whereas [he]35-walter looked to find wild fruits here and there and to shoot some small deer , as hare or coney , and make a shift to cook the same , since [he]35-walter had with [him]35-walter flint and fire - steel . Moreover the further [he]35-walter went , the surer [he]35-walter was that [he]35-walter should soon come across [a dwelling]495-a dwelling , so smooth and fair as everything looked before [him]35-walter . And [he]35-walter had scant fear , save that [he]35-walter might happen on [men who should enthrall [him]35-walter]496-men who should enthrall him .

But when [he]35-walter was come down past [the first green slopes]497-the first green slopes , [he]35-walter was so worn , that [he]35-walter said to [himself]35-walter that rest was better than meat , so little as [he]35-walter had slept for the last three days ; so [he]35-walter laid [him]35-walter down under an ash - tree by [a stream - side]498-a stream - side , nor asked what was o'clock , but had [his]35-walter fill of sleep , and even when [he]35-walter awoke in the fresh morning was little fain of rising , but lay betwixt sleeping and waking for some three hours more ; then [he]35-walter arose , and went further down [the next green bent]499-the next green bent , yet somewhat slowly because of [his]35-walter hunger - weakness . And the scent of [that fair land]500-that fair land came up to [him]35-walter like the odour of one great nosegay .

So [he]35-walter came to where [the land]101-the land was level , and there were many trees , as oak and ash , and sweet - chestnut and wych - elm , and hornbeam and quicken - tree , not growing in a close wood or tangled thicket , but set as though in order on the flowery greensward , even as it might be in [a great king 's park]502-a great king 's park .

So came [he]35-walter to a big bird - cherry , whereof many boughs hung low down laden with fruit : [his]35-walter belly rejoiced at the sight , and [he]35-walter caught hold of a bough , and fell to plucking and eating . But whiles [he]35-walter was amidst of this , [he]35-walter heard suddenly , close anigh [him]35-walter , a strange noise of roaring and braying , not very great , but exceeding fierce and terrible , and not like to the voice of any beast that [he]35-walter knew . As has been aforesaid , [Walter]53-walter was no faint - heart ; but what with the weakness of [his]53-walter travail and hunger , what with the strangeness of [his]53-walter adventure and [his]53-walter loneliness , [his]53-walter spirit failed [him]53-walter ; [he]53-walter turned round towards the noise , [his]53-walter knees shook and [he]53-walter trembled : this way and that [he]53-walter looked , and then gave a great cry and tumbled down in a swoon ; for close before [him]53-walter , at [his]53-walter very feet , was [the dwarf whose image [he]53-walter had seen before , clad in [his]503-the dwarf whose image he had seen before , clad in his yellow coat , and grinning up at him from his hideous hairy countenance yellow coat , and grinning up at [him]53-walter from [his]503-the dwarf whose image he had seen before , clad in his yellow coat , and grinning up at him from his hideous hairy countenance hideous hairy countenance]503-the dwarf whose image he had seen before , clad in his yellow coat , and grinning up at him from his hideous hairy countenance .

How long [he]53-walter lay there as [one dead]504-one dead , [he]53-walter knew not , but when [he]53-walter woke again there was [the dwarf]182-the dwarf sitting on [his]53-walter hams close by [him]53-walter . And when [he]53-walter lifted up [his]53-walter head , [the dwarf]182-the dwarf sent out that fearful harsh voice again ; but this time [Walter]53-walter could make out words therein , and knew that [the creature]507-the creature spoke and said :

" How now ! What art [thou]507-the creature ? Whence comest ? What wantest ? "[507-the creature]

[Walter]53-walter sat up and said : " [I]53-walter am [a man]229-a man ; [I]53-walter hight [Golden Walter]35-walter ; [I]53-walter come from [Langton]35-walter ; [I]53-walter want victual . "[53-walter]

Said [the dwarf]182-the dwarf , writhing [his]182-the dwarf face grievously , and laughing forsooth : " [I]182-the dwarf know it all : [I]182-the dwarf asked [thee]53-walter to see what wise [thou]53-walter wouldst lie . [I]182-the dwarf was sent forth to look for [thee]53-walter ; and [I]182-the dwarf have brought [thee]53-walter loathsome bread with [me]182-the dwarf , such as [ye]53-walter [aliens]137-aliens must needs eat : take it ! "[182-the dwarf]

Therewith [he]182-the dwarf drew a loaf from a satchel which [he]182-the dwarf bore , and thrust it towards [Walter]35-walter , who took it somewhat doubtfully for all [his]35-walter hunger .

[The dwarf]182-the dwarf yelled at [him]35-walter : " Art [thou]53-walter dainty , alien ? Wouldst [thou]53-walter have flesh ? Well , give [me]182-the dwarf [thy]53-walter bow and an arrow or two , since [thou]53-walter art lazy- sick , and [I]182-the dwarf will get [thee]53-walter a coney or a hare , or a quail maybe . Ah , [I]182-the dwarf forgot ; [thou]53-walter art dainty , and wilt not eat flesh as [I]182-the dwarf do , blood and all together , but must needs half burn it in the fire , or mar it with hot water ; as [they]1766-they say [[my]182-the dwarf Lady]1767-my lady does : or as [the Wretch]1768-the wretch , the Thing does ; [I]182-the dwarf know that , for [I]182-the dwarf have seen [It]1768-the wretch eating . "[182-the dwarf]

" Nay , "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter , " this sufficeth ; "[35-walter] and [he]35-walter fell to eating the bread , which was sweet between [his]35-walter teeth . Then when [he]35-walter had eaten a while , for hunger compelled [him]35-walter , [he]35-walter said to [the dwarf]182-the dwarf : " But what meanest [thou]53-walter by [the Wretch]54-the wretch and the Thing ? And what [Lady]1769-lady is [[thy]53-walter Lady]1770-thy lady ? "[35-walter]

[The creature]507-the creature let out another wordless roar as of furious anger ; and then the words came : " It hath a face white and red , like to thine ; and hands white as thine , yea , but whiter ; and the like it is underneath its raiment , only whiter still : for [I]507-the creature have seen [It]507-the creature - yes , [I]507-the creature have seen [It]507-the creature ; ah yes and yes and yes . "[507-the creature]

And therewith [his]35-walter words ran into gibber and yelling , and [he]35-walter rolled about and smote at the grass : but in a while [he]35-walter grew quiet again and sat still , and then fell to laughing horribly again , and then said : " But [thou]53-walter , [fool]1771-fool , wilt think [It]507-the creature fair if [thou]53-walter fallest into [Its]507-the creature hands , and wilt repent it thereafter , as [I]35-walter did . Oh , the mocking and gibes of It , and the tears and shrieks of It ; and the knife ! What ! sayest [thou]53-walter of [[my]35-walter Lady]1767-my lady ? - What [Lady]1773-lady ? O alien , what [other Lady]1774-other lady is there ? And what shall [I]35-walter tell [thee]53-walter of [her]1773-lady ? it is like that [she]1773-lady made [me]35-walter , as [she]1773-lady made [the Bear men]1775-the bear men . But [she]1773-lady made not the Wretch , the Thing ; and [she]1773-lady hateth [It]507-the creature sorely , as [I]35-walter do . And some day to come - "[35-walter]

Thereat [he]512-his brake off and fell to wordless yelling a long while , and thereafter spake all panting : " Now [I]512-his have told [thee]53-walter overmuch , and O if [[my]512-his Lady]1767-my lady come to hear thereof . Now [I]512-his will go . "[512-his]

And therewith [he]512-his took out two more loaves from [his]512-his wallet , and tossed them to [Walter]35-walter , and so turned and went [his]512-his ways ; whiles walking upright , as [Walter]35-walter had seen [his]512-his image on [the quay of [Langton]35-walter]513-the quay of langton ; whiles bounding and rolling like a ball thrown by [a lad]514-a lad ; whiles scuttling along on all - fours like an evil beast , and ever and [anon giving forth that harsh and evil cry]515-anon giving forth that harsh and evil cry .

[Walter]35-walter sat a while after [he]35-walter was out of sight , so stricken with horror and loathing and a fear of [he]35-walter knew not what , that [he]35-walter might not move . Then [he]35-walter plucked up a heart , and looked to [his]35-walter weapons and put the other loaves into [his]35-walter scrip .

Then [he]35-walter arose and went [his]35-walter ways wondering , yea and dreading , what kind of creature [he]35-walter should next fall in with . For soothly it seemed to [him]35-walter that it would be worse than death if [they]516-they were [all such as this one]517-all such as this one ; and that if it were so , [he]35-walter must needs slay and be slain .

CHAPTER X : [WALTER]35-walter HAPPENETH ON ANOTHER CREATURE IN [THE STRANGE LAND]11-a new land

But as [he]35-walter went on through [the fair and sweet land]518-the fair and sweet land so bright and sun - litten , and [he]35-walter now rested and fed , the horror and fear ran off from [him]35-walter , and [he]35-walter wandered on merrily , neither did aught befall [him]35-walter save the coming of night , when [he]35-walter laid [him]35-walter down under a great spreading oak with [his]35-walter drawn sword ready to hand , and fell asleep at once , and woke not till the sun was high .

Then [he]35-walter arose and went on [his]35-walter way again ; and [the land]101-the land was no worser than yesterday ; but even better , it might be ; the greensward more flowery , the oaks and chestnuts greater . Deer of diverse kinds [he]35-walter saw , and might easily have got [his]35-walter meat thereof ; but [he]35-walter meddled not with them since [he]35-walter had [his]35-walter bread , and was timorous of lighting a fire . Withal [he]35-walter doubted little of having some entertainment ; and that , might be , nought evil ; since even [that fearful dwarf]520-that fearful dwarf had been courteous to [him]35-walter after [his]35-walter kind , and had done [him]35-walter good and not harm . But of the happening on the Wretch and the Thing , whereof [the dwarf]182-the dwarf spake , [he]35-walter was yet somewhat afeard .

After [he]35-walter had gone a while and whenas the summer morn was at its brightest , [he]35-walter saw a little way ahead a grey rock rising up from amidst of a ring of oak - trees ; so [he]35-walter turned thither straightway ; for in [this plain- land]522-this plain- land [he]35-walter had seen no rocks heretofore ; and as [he]35-walter went [he]35-walter saw that there was a fountain gushing out from under [the rock]523-the rock , which ran thence in a fair little stream . And when [he]35-walter had the rock and the fountain and the stream clear before [him]35-walter , lo ! [a child of [Adam]49-adam]524-a child of adam sitting beside [the fountain under the shadow of the rock]525-the fountain under the shadow of the rock . [He]35-walter drew a little nigher , and then [he]35-walter saw that it was [a woman]526-a woman , clad in green like the sward whereon [she]526-a woman lay . [She]526-a woman was playing with the welling out of [the water]527-the water , and [she]526-a woman had trussed up [her]526-a woman sleeves to the shoulder that [she]526-a woman might thrust [her]526-a woman bare arms therein . [Her]526-a woman shoes of black leather lay on the grass beside [her]526-a woman , and [her]526-a woman feet and legs yet shone with [the brook]528-the brook .

Belike amidst the splashing and clatter of the water [she]526-a woman did not hear [him]35-walter drawing nigh , so that [he]35-walter was close to [her]526-a woman before [she]526-a woman lifted up [her]526-a woman face and saw [him]35-walter , and [he]35-walter beheld [her]526-a woman , that it was [the maiden of the thrice - seen pageant]529-the maiden of the thrice - seen pageant . [She]526-a woman reddened when [she]526-a woman saw [him]35-walter , and hastily covered up [her]526-a woman legs with [her]526-a woman gown - skirt , and drew down the sleeves over [her]526-a woman arms , but otherwise stirred not . As for [him]35-walter , [he]35-walter stood still , striving to speak to [her]526-a woman ; but no word might [he]35-walter bring out , and [his]35-walter heart beat sorely .

But [the maiden]183-the maiden spake to [him]35-walter in a clear sweet voice , wherein was now no trouble : " [Thou]35-walter art [an alien]1777-an alien , art [thou]35-walter not ? For [I]183-the maiden have not seen [thee]35-walter before . "[183-the maiden]

" [Yea]1778-yea , "[35-walter] [he]35-walter said , " [I]35-walter am [an alien]1777-an alien ; wilt [thou]35-walter be good to [me]35-walter ? "[35-walter]

[She]526-a woman said : " And why not ? [I]526-a woman was afraid at first , for [I]526-a woman thought it had been [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son . [I]526-a woman looked to see [none other]1653-none other ; for of [goodly men]1783-goodly men [he]1781-the king 's son has been [the only one here in [the land]101-the land]1784-the only one here in the land this long while , till [thy]526-a woman coming . "[526-a woman]

[He]35-walter said : " Didst [thou]35-walter look for [my]35-walter coming at about this time ? "[35-walter]

" O nay , "[526-a woman] [she]526-a woman said ; " how might [I]526-a woman ? "[526-a woman]

Said [Walter]35-walter : " [I]35-walter wot not ; but [the other man]1786-the other man seemed to be looking for [me]35-walter , and knew of [me]35-walter , and [he]1786-the other man brought [me]35-walter bread to eat . "[35-walter]

[She]526-a woman looked on [him]35-walter anxiously , and grew somewhat pale , as [she]526-a woman said : " [What other one]1787-what other one ? "[526-a woman]

Now [Walter]35-walter did not know what [the dwarf]182-the dwarf might be to [her]526-a woman , [fellow - servant]532-fellow - servant or what not , so [he]35-walter would not show [his]35-walter loathing of [him]182-the dwarf ; but answered wisely : " [The little man in the yellow raiment]1788-the little man in the yellow raiment . "[35-walter]

But when [she]526-a woman heard that word , [she]526-a woman went suddenly very pale , and leaned [her]526-a woman head aback , and beat the air with [her]526-a woman hands ; but said presently in a faint voice : " [I]526-a woman pray [thee]526-a woman talk not of that one while [I]526-a woman am by , nor even think of [him]1788-the little man in the yellow raiment , if [thou]526-a woman mayest forbear . "[526-a woman]

[He]35-walter spake not , and [she]526-a woman was a little while before [she]526-a woman came to [herself]526-a woman again ; then [she]526-a woman opened [her]526-a woman eyes , and looked upon [Walter]35-walter and smiled kindly on [him]35-walter , as though to ask [his]35-walter pardon for having scared [him]35-walter . Then [she]526-a woman rose up in [her]526-a woman place , and stood before [him]35-walter ; and [they]533-they were nigh together , for the stream betwixt [them]533-they was little .

But [he]35-walter still looked anxiously upon [her]526-a woman and said : " Have [I]35-walter hurt [thee]526-a woman ? [I]35-walter pray [thy]526-a woman pardon . "[35-walter]

[She]526-a woman looked on [him]35-walter more sweetly still , and said : " O nay ; [thou]526-a woman wouldst not hurt [me]526-a woman , [thou]526-a woman ! "[526-a woman]

Then [she]526-a woman blushed very red , and [he]35-walter in like wise ; but afterwards [she]526-a woman turned pale , and laid a hand on [her]526-a woman breast , and [Walter]35-walter cried out hastily : " O [me]35-walter ! [I]35-walter have hurt [thee]526-a woman again . Wherein have [I]35-walter done amiss ? "[35-walter]

" In nought , in nought , "[526-a woman] [she]526-a woman said ; " but [I]526-a woman am troubled , [I]526-a woman wot not wherefore ; some thought hath taken hold of [me]526-a woman , and [I]526-a woman know it not . Mayhappen in a little while [I]526-a woman shall know what troubles [me]526-a woman . Now [I]526-a woman bid [thee]534-thee depart from [me]526-a woman a little , and [I]526-a woman will abide here ; and when [thou]534-thee comest back , it will either be that [I]526-a woman have found it out or not ; and in either case [I]526-a woman will tell [thee]534-thee . "[526-a woman]

[She]526-a woman spoke earnestly to [him]534-thee ; but [he]534-thee said : " How long shall [I]526-a woman abide away ? "[526-a woman]

[Her]526-a woman face was troubled as [she]526-a woman answered [him]534-thee : " For no long while . "[526-a woman]

[He]534-thee smiled on [her]526-a woman and turned away , and went a space to [the other side of the oak - trees]535-the other side of the oak - trees , whence [she]526-a woman was still within eyeshot . There [he]534-thee abode until the time seemed long to [him]534-thee ; but [he]534-thee schooled [himself]534-thee and forbore ; for [he]534-thee said : Lest [she]526-a woman send [me]0-i away again . So [he]534-thee abided until again the time seemed long to [him]534-thee , and [she]526-a woman called not to [him]534-thee : but once again [he]534-thee forbore to go ; then at last [he]534-thee arose , and [his]534-thee heart beat and [he]534-thee trembled , and [he]534-thee walked back again speedily , and came to [the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring , [her]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring arms hanging down , [her]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring eyes downcast . [She]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring looked up at [him]534-thee as [he]534-thee drew nigh , and [her]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring face changed with eagerness as [she]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring said : " [I]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring am glad [thou]534-thee art come back , though it be no long while since [thy]534-thee departure "[536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring] sooth to say it was scarce half an hour in all . " Nevertheless [I]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring have been thinking many things , and thereof will [I]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring now tell [thee]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring . "[536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring]

[He]534-thee said : " [Maiden]55-maiden , there is [a river betwixt]1789-a river betwixt [us]1790-us , though it be no big one . Shall [I]534-thee not stride over , and come to [thee]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring , that [we]1790-us may sit down together side by side on the green grass ? "[534-thee]

" Nay , "[536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring] [she]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring said , " not yet ; tarry a while till [I]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring have told [thee]534-thee of matters . [I]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring must now tell [thee]534-thee of [my]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring thoughts in order . "[536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring]

[Her]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring colour went and came now , and [she]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring plaited the folds of [her]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring gown with restless fingers . At last [she]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring said : " Now the first thing is this ; that though [thou]534-thee hast seen [me]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring first only within this hour , [thou]534-thee hast set thine heart upon [me]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring to have [me]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring for [thy]534-thee speech - friend and [[thy]534-thee darling]1791-thy darling . And if this be not so , then is all [my]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring speech , yea and all [my]536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring hope , come to an end at once . "[536-the maiden , who was still standing by the rock of the spring]

" O [yea]1792-yea ! "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter , " even so it is : but how [thou]534-thee hast found this out [I]35-walter wot not ; since now for the first time [I]35-walter say it , that [thou]534-thee art indeed [[my]35-walter love]1793-my love , and [[my]35-walter dear]1794-my dear and [[my]35-walter darling]1795-my darling . "[35-walter]

" Hush , "[537-i] [she]537-i said , " hush ! lest the wood have ears , and [thy]534-thee speech is loud : abide , and [I]537-i shall tell [thee]534-thee how [I]537-i know it . Whether this [thy]534-thee love shall outlast the first time that [thou]534-thee holdest [my]537-i body in thine arms , [I]537-i wot not , nor dost [thou]534-thee . But sore is [my]537-i hope that it may be so ; for [I]537-i also , though it be but scarce an hour since [I]537-i set eyes on [thee]534-thee , have cast [mine]537-i eyes on [thee]534-thee to have [thee]534-thee for [my]537-i love and [[my]537-i darling]1795-my darling , and [[my]537-i speech - friend]1797-my speech - friend . And this is how [I]537-i wot that [thou]534-thee lovest [me]537-i , [[my]537-i friend]1798-my friend . Now is all this dear and joyful , and overflows [my]537-i heart with sweetness . But now must [I]537-i tell [thee]534-thee of the fear and the evil which lieth behind it . "[537-i]

Then [Walter]35-walter stretched out [his]35-walter hands to [her]538-she , and cried out : " [Yea]1799-yea , [yea]1799-yea ! But whatever evil entangle [us]1800-we , now [we]1800-we both know these two things , to wit , that [thou]534-thee lovest [me]35-walter , and [I]35-walter [thee]534-thee , wilt [thou]534-thee not come hither , that [I]35-walter may cast [mine]35-walter arms about [thee]534-thee , and kiss [thee]534-thee , if not [thy]534-thee kind lips or [thy]534-thee friendly face at all , yet at least [thy]534-thee dear hand : yea , that [I]35-walter may touch [thy]534-thee body in some wise ? "[35-walter]

[She]538-she looked on [him]539-him steadily , and said softly : " Nay , this above all things must not be ; and that it may not be is a part of the evil which entangles [us]1800-we . But hearken , [friend]1695-friend , once again [I]538-she tell [thee]534-thee that [thy]534-thee voice is over loud in this wilderness fruitful of evil . Now [I]538-she have told [thee]534-thee , indeed , of two things whereof [we]1800-we both wot ; but next [I]538-she must needs tell [thee]534-thee of things whereof [I]538-she wot , and [thou]534-thee wottest not . Yet this were better , that [thou]534-thee pledge [thy]534-thee word not to touch so much as one of [my]538-she hands , and that [we]1800-we go together a little way hence away from these tumbled stones , and sit down upon the open greensward ; whereas here is cover if there be spying abroad . "[538-she]

Again , as [she]538-she spoke , [she]538-she turned very pale ; but [Walter]35-walter said : " Since it must be so , [I]35-walter pledge [thee]534-thee [my]35-walter word to [thee]534-thee as [I]35-walter love [thee]534-thee . "[35-walter]

And therewith [she]538-she knelt down , and did on [her]538-she foot - gear , and then sprang lightly over the rivulet ; and then the twain of [them]540-them went side by side some half a furlong thence , and sat down , shadowed by the boughs of a slim quicken - tree growing up out of the greensward , whereon for a good space around was neither bush nor brake .

There began [the maiden]183-the maiden to talk soberly , and said : " This is what [I]183-the maiden must needs say to [thee]534-thee now , that [thou]534-thee art come into [a land perilous for any one that loveth aught of good]1802-a land perilous for any one that loveth aught of good ; from which , forsooth , [I]183-the maiden were fain that [thou]534-thee wert gotten away safely , even though [I]183-the maiden should die of longing for [thee]534-thee . As for [myself]183-the maiden , [my]183-the maiden peril is , in a measure , less than thine ; [I]183-the maiden mean the peril of death . But lo , [thou]534-thee , this iron on [my]183-the maiden foot is token that [I]183-the maiden am [a thrall]1803-a thrall , and [thou]534-thee knowest in what [wise thralls]1804-wise thralls must pay for transgressions . Furthermore , of what [I]183-the maiden am , and how [I]183-the maiden came hither , time would fail [me]183-the maiden to tell ; but somewhile , maybe , [I]183-the maiden shall tell [thee]534-thee . [I]183-the maiden serve [an evil mistress]1805-an evil mistress , of whom [I]183-the maiden may say that scarce [I]183-the maiden wot if [she]1805-an evil mistress be [a woman]526-a woman or not ; but by some creatures is [she]1805-an evil mistress accounted for [a god]1807-a god , and as [a god]1807-a god is [heried]1805-an evil mistress ; and surely never [god]1809-god was crueller nor colder than [she]1805-an evil mistress . [Me]183-the maiden [she]1805-an evil mistress hateth sorely ; yet if [she]1805-an evil mistress hated [me]183-the maiden little or nought , small were the gain to [me]183-the maiden if it were [her]1805-an evil mistress pleasure to deal hardly by [me]183-the maiden . But as things now are , and are like to be , it would not be for [her]1805-an evil mistress pleasure , but for [her]1805-an evil mistress pain and loss , to make an end of [me]183-the maiden , therefore , as [I]183-the maiden said e'en now , [my]183-the maiden mere life is not in peril with [her]1805-an evil mistress ; unless , perchance , some sudden passion get the better of [her]1805-an evil mistress , and [she]1805-an evil mistress slay [me]183-the maiden , and repent of it thereafter . For so it is , that if it be the least evil of [her]1805-an evil mistress conditions that [she]1805-an evil mistress is wanton , at least wanton [she]1805-an evil mistress is to the letter . Many a time hath [she]1805-an evil mistress cast the net for the catching of [some goodly young man]1810-some goodly young man ; and [her]1805-an evil mistress latest prey save it be [thou]1811-thou is [the young man whom [I]183-the maiden named , when first [I]183-the maiden saw [thee]1805-an evil mistress , by the name of [the King]1780-the king 's Son]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son . [He]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son is with [us]1814-us yet , and [I]183-the maiden fear [him]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son ; for of late hath [he]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son wearied of [her]1805-an evil mistress , though it is but plain truth to say of [her]1805-an evil mistress , that [she]1805-an evil mistress is the wonder of all Beauties of [the World]118-the world . [He]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son hath wearied of [her]1805-an evil mistress , [I]183-the maiden say , and [hath]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son cast [his]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son eyes upon [me]183-the maiden , and if [I]183-the maiden were heedless , [he]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son would betray [me]183-the maiden to the uttermost of the wrath of [[my]183-the maiden mistress]1816-my mistress . For needs must [I]183-the maiden say of [him]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son , though [he]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son be [a goodly man]1817-a goodly man , and now fallen into thralldom , that [he]1812-the young man whom i named , when first i saw thee , by the name of the king 's son hath no bowels of compassion ; but is a dastard , who for an hour 's pleasure would undo [me]183-the maiden , and thereafter would stand by smiling and taking [[my]183-the maiden mistress]1816-my mistress 's pardon with good cheer , while for [me]183-the maiden would be no pardon . Seest [thou]1819-thou , therefore , how it is with [me]183-the maiden between [these two cruel fools]1820-these two cruel fools ? And moreover there are others of whom [I]183-the maiden will not even speak to [thee]542-her . "[183-the maiden]

And therewith [she]542-her put [her]542-her hands before [her]542-her face , and wept , and murmured : " Who shall deliver [me]542-her from this death in life ? "[542-her]

But [Walter]35-walter cried out : " For what else am [I]35-walter come hither , [I]35-walter , [I]35-walter ? "[35-walter]

And it was a near thing that [he]35-walter did not take [her]542-her in [his]35-walter arms , but [he]35-walter remembered [his]35-walter pledged word , and drew aback from [her]542-her in terror , whereas [he]35-walter had an inkling of why [she]542-her would not suffer it ; and [he]35-walter wept with [her]542-her .

But suddenly [the Maid]543-the maid left weeping , and said in a changed voice : " [Friend]1695-friend , whereas [thou]543-the maid speakest of delivering [me]543-the maid , it is more like that [I]543-the maid shall deliver [thee]1695-friend . And now [I]543-the maid pray [thy]543-the maid pardon for thus grieving [thee]1695-friend with [my]543-the maid grief , and that more especially because [thou]543-the maid mayst not solace [thy]543-the maid grief with kisses and caresses ; but so it was , that for once [I]543-the maid was smitten by the thought of the anguish of [this land]1735-this land , and the joy of all [the world]118-the world besides . "[543-the maid]

Therewith [she]542-her caught [her]542-her breath in a half - sob , but refrained [her]542-her and went on : " Now [dear friend]1824-dear friend and [darling]1825-darling , take good heed to all that [I]542-her shall say to [thee]1695-friend , whereas [thou]543-the maid must do after the teaching of [my]542-her words . And first , [I]542-her deem by the monster having met [thee]1695-friend at [the gates of [the land]101-the land]1826-the gates of the land , and refreshed [thee]1695-friend , that [the Mistress]1828-the mistress hath looked for [thy]1695-friend coming ; nay , by [thy]1695-friend coming hither at all , that [she]1828-the mistress hath cast [her]1828-the mistress net and caught [thee]1695-friend . Hast [thou]543-the maid noted aught that might seem to make this more like ? "[542-her]

Said [Walter]35-walter : " Three times in full daylight have [I]35-walter seen go past [me]35-walter the images of [the monster]1829-the monster and [thee]1695-friend and [a glorious lady]1830-a glorious lady , even as if [ye]1695-friend were alive . "[35-walter]

And therewith [he]35-walter told [her]544-i in few words how it had gone with [him]35-walter since that day on [the quay at [Langton]35-walter]545-the quay at langton .

[She]544-i said : " Then it is no longer perhaps , but certain , that [thou]1695-friend art [her]1828-the mistress latest catch ; and even so [I]544-i deemed from the first : and , [dear friend]1824-dear friend , this is why [I]544-i have not suffered [thee]1695-friend to kiss or caress [me]544-i , so sore as [I]544-i longed for [thee]1695-friend . For [the Mistress]1828-the mistress will have [thee]1695-friend for [her]1828-the mistress only , and hath lured [thee]1695-friend hither for nought else ; and [she]1828-the mistress is wise in wizardry even as some deal am [I]544-i , and wert [thou]1695-friend to touch [me]544-i with hand or mouth on [my]544-i naked flesh , yea , or were it even [my]544-i raiment , then would [she]1828-the mistress scent the savour of [thy]1695-friend love upon [me]544-i , and then , though it may be [she]1828-the mistress would spare [thee]1695-friend , [she]1828-the mistress would not spare [me]544-i . "[544-i]

Then was [she]546-she silent a little , and seemed very downcast , and [Walter]35-walter held [his]35-walter peace from grief and confusion and helplessness ; for of wizardry [he]35-walter knew nought .

At last [the Maid]543-the maid spake again , and said : " Nevertheless [we]1833-we will not die redeless . Now [thou]1695-friend must look to this , that from henceforward it is [thee]1695-friend , and not [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son [, whom [she]1828-the mistress desireth , and that so much the more that [she]1828-the mistress hath not set eyes on [thee]1695-friend]1836-, whom she desireth , and that so much the more that she hath not set eyes on thee . Remember this , whatsoever [her]1828-the mistress seeming may be to [thee]1695-friend . Now , therefore , shall [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son be free , though [he]1781-the king 's son know it not , to cast [his]1781-the king 's son love on whomso [he]1781-the king 's son will ; and , in a way , [I]543-the maid also shall be free to yeasay [him]1781-the king 's son . Though , forsooth , so fulfilled is [she]548-she with malice and spite , that even then [she]548-she may turn round on [me]543-the maid to punish [me]543-the maid for doing that which [she]548-she would have [me]543-the maid do . Now let [me]543-the maid think of it . "[543-the maid]

Then was [she]548-she silent a good while , and spoke at last : " [Yea]1695-friend , all things are perilous , and a perilous rede [I]548-she have thought of , whereof [I]548-she will not tell [thee]1695-friend as yet ; so waste not the short while by asking [me]548-she . At least the worst will be no worse than what shall come if [we]1839-we strive not against it . And now , [[my]548-she friend]1798-my friend , amongst perils it is growing more and more perilous that [we]1839-we twain should be longer together . But [I]548-she would say one thing yet ; and maybe another thereafter . [Thou]1841-thy hast cast [thy]1841-thy love upon one who will be true to [thee]1841-thy , whatsoever may befall ; yet is [she]548-she a guileful creature , and might not help it [her]548-she life long , and now for [thy]1841-thy very sake must needs be more guileful now than ever before . And as for [me]548-she , the guileful , [my]548-she love have [I]548-she cast upon [a lovely man , and one true and simple , and a stout- heart]1842-a lovely man , and one true and simple , and a stout- heart ; but at such a pinch is [he]1842-a lovely man , and one true and simple , and a stout- heart , that if [he]1842-a lovely man , and one true and simple , and a stout- heart withstand all temptation , [his]1842-a lovely man , and one true and simple , and a stout- heart withstanding may belike undo both [him]1842-a lovely man , and one true and simple , and a stout- heart and [me]548-she . Therefore swear [[we]1839-we both of [us]1839-we]1843-we both of us , that by both of [us]1839-we shall all guile and all falling away be forgiven on the day when [we]1839-we shall be free to love [each the other]1844-each the other as [our]1839-we hearts will . "[548-she]

[Walter]35-walter cried out : " O love , [I]35-walter swear it indeed ! [thou]1845-thou art [my]35-walter Hallow , and [I]35-walter will swear it as on the relics of a Hallow ; on [thy]1845-thou hands and [thy]1845-thou feet [I]35-walter swear it . "[35-walter]

The words seemed to [her]549-i a dear caress ; and [she]549-i laughed , and blushed , and looked full kindly on [him]35-walter ; and then [her]549-i face grew solemn , and [she]549-i said : " On [thy]1845-thou life [I]549-i swear it ! "[549-i]

Then [she]549-i said : " Now is there nought for [thee]1845-thou to do but to go hence straight to [the Golden House]1846-the golden house , which is [[[my]549-i Mistress]1816-my mistress 's house]1848-my mistress 's house , and [the only house in [this land]1735-this land]1849-the only house in this land save one which [I]549-i may not see , and lieth southward no long way . How [she]549-i will deal with [thee]1845-thou , [I]549-i wot not ; but all [I]549-i have said of [her]549-i and [thee]1845-thou and [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son is true . Therefore [I]549-i say to [thee]1845-thou , be wary and cold at heart , whatsoever outward semblance [thou]1845-thou mayst make . If [thou]1845-thou have to yield [thee]1845-thou to [her]549-i , then yield rather late than early , so as to gain time . Yet not so late as to seem shamed in yielding for fear 's sake . Hold fast to [thy]1845-thou life , [[my]549-i friend]1798-my friend , for in warding that , [thou]1845-thou wardest [me]549-i from grief without remedy . [Thou]1845-thou wilt see [me]549-i ere long ; it may be to - morrow , it may be some days hence . But forget not , that what [I]549-i may do , that [I]549-i am doing . Take heed also that [thou]1845-thou pay no more heed to [me]549-i , or rather less , than if [thou]1845-thou wert meeting [a maiden of no account in [the streets of [thine own town]1856-thine own town]1855-the streets of thine own town]1854-a maiden of no account in the streets of thine own town . O [[my]549-i love]1793-my love ! barren is this first farewell , as was [our]1858-our first meeting ; but surely shall there be another meeting better than the first , and the last farewell may be long and long yet . "[549-i]

Therewith [she]550-she stood up , and [he]551-he knelt before [her]550-she a little while without any word , and then arose and went [his]551-he ways ; but when [he]551-he had gone a space [he]551-he turned about , and saw [her]550-she still standing in the same place ; [she]550-she stayed a moment when [she]550-she saw [him]551-he turn , and then [herself]550-she turned about .

So [he]551-he departed through [the fair land]552-the fair land , and [his]551-he heart was full with hope and fear as [he]551-he went .

CHAPTER XI : [WALTER]35-walter HAPPENETH ON [THE MISTRESS]1828-the mistress

It was but a little after noon when [Walter]35-walter left [the Maid]543-the maid behind : [he]35-walter steered south by the sun , as [the Maid]543-the maid had bidden [him]35-walter , and went swiftly ; for , as [a good knight wending to battle]556-a good knight wending to battle , the time seemed long to [him]35-walter till [he]35-walter should meet [the foe]557-the foe .

So an hour before sunset [he]35-walter saw something white and gay gleaming through the boles of the oak - trees , and presently there was clear before [him]35-walter [a most goodly house]558-a most goodly house builded of white marble , carved all about with knots and imagery , and [the carven folk]559-the carven folk were all painted of [their]559-the carven folk lively colours , whether it were [their]559-the carven folk raiment or [their]559-the carven folk flesh , and the housings wherein [they]559-the carven folk stood all done with gold and fair hues . Gay were the windows of [the house]112-the house ; and there was [a pillared porch]561-a pillared porch before the great door , with images betwixt the pillars both of [men]165-men and beasts : and when [Walter]35-walter looked up to the roof of [the house]112-the house , [he]35-walter saw that it gleamed and shone ; for all the tiles were of yellow metal , which [he]35-walter deemed to be of very gold .

All this [he]35-walter saw as [he]35-walter went , and tarried not to gaze upon it ; for [he]35-walter said , Belike there will be time for [me]0-i to look on all this before [I]0-i die . But [he]35-walter said also , that , though [the house]112-the house was not of the greatest , it was beyond compare of [all houses of [the world]118-the world]565-all houses of the world .

Now [he]35-walter entered [it]112-the house by [the porch]567-the porch , and came into [a hall many - pillared , and vaulted over]568-a hall many - pillared , and vaulted over , the walls painted with gold and ultramarine , the floor dark , and spangled with many colours , and the windows glazed with knots and pictures . Midmost thereof was a fountain of gold , whence the water ran two ways in gold - lined runnels , spanned twice with little bridges of silver . Long was [that hall]569-that hall , and now not very light , so that [Walter]35-walter was come past the fountain before [he]35-walter saw [any folk therein]570-any folk therein : then [he]35-walter looked up toward the high - seat , and himseemed that a great light shone thence , and dazzled [his]35-walter eyes ; and [he]35-walter went on a little way , and then fell on [his]35-walter knees ; for there before [him]35-walter on the high - seat sat [that wondrous Lady]571-that wondrous lady , whose lively image had been shown to [him]35-walter thrice before ; and [she]571-that wondrous lady was clad in gold and jewels , as [he]35-walter had erst seen [her]571-that wondrous lady . But now [she]571-that wondrous lady was not alone ; for by [her]571-that wondrous lady side sat [a young man]87-a young man , goodly enough , so far as [Walter]35-walter might see [him]87-a young man , and most richly clad , with a jewelled sword by [his]87-a young man side , and a chaplet of gems on [his]87-a young man head . [They]573-they held [each other]421-each other by the hand , and seemed to be in dear converse together ; but [they]573-they spake softly , so that [Walter]35-walter might not hear what [they]573-they said , till at last [the man]1710-the man spake aloud to [the Lady]576-the lady : " Seest [thou]576-the lady not that there is [a man]229-a man in [the hall]1860-the hall ? "[1710-the man]

" [Yea]1861-yea , "[576-the lady] [she]576-the lady said , " [I]576-the lady see [him]229-a man yonder , kneeling on [his]229-a man knees ; let [him]229-a man come nigher and give some account of [himself]229-a man . "[576-the lady]

So [Walter]35-walter stood up and drew nigh , and stood there , all shamefaced and confused , looking on [those twain]577-those twain , and wondering at the beauty of [the Lady]576-the lady . As for [the man , who was slim , and black - haired , and straight - featured]579-the man , who was slim , and black - haired , and straight - featured , for all [his]579-the man , who was slim , and black - haired , and straight - featured goodliness [Walter]35-walter accounted [him]579-the man , who was slim , and black - haired , and straight - featured little , and nowise deemed [him]579-the man , who was slim , and black - haired , and straight - featured to look chieftain - like .

Now [the Lady]576-the lady spake not to [Walter]35-walter any more than erst ; but at last [the man]1710-the man said : " Why doest [thou]1710-the man not kneel as [thou]1710-the man didst erewhile ? "[1710-the man]

[Walter]35-walter was on the point of giving [him]1710-the man back a fierce answer ; but [the Lady]576-the lady spake and said : " Nay , [friend]1695-friend , it matters not whether [he]1710-the man kneel or stand ; but [he]1710-the man may say , if [he]1710-the man will , what [he]1710-the man would have of [me]576-the lady , and wherefore [he]1710-the man is come hither . "[576-the lady]

Then spake [Walter]35-walter , for as wroth and ashamed as [he]35-walter was : " [Lady]1863-lady , [I]35-walter have strayed into [this land]1735-this land , and have come to [thine house]1762-thine house as [I]35-walter suppose , and if [I]35-walter be not welcome , [I]35-walter may well depart straightway , and seek a way out of [[thy]576-the lady land]1866-thy land , if [thou]576-the lady wouldst drive [me]35-walter thence , as well as out of [thine house]1762-thine house . "[35-walter]

Thereat [the Lady]576-the lady turned and looked on [him]35-walter , and when [her]576-the lady eyes met [his]35-walter , [he]35-walter felt a pang of fear and desire mingled shoot through [his]35-walter heart . This time [she]576-the lady spoke to [him]35-walter ; but coldly , without either wrath or any thought of [him]35-walter : " [Newcomer]56-newcomer , "[576-the lady] [she]576-the lady said , " [I]576-the lady have not bidden [thee]35-walter hither ; but here mayst [thou]35-walter abide a while if [thou]35-walter wilt ; nevertheless , take heed that here is [[no King]1868-no king 's Court]1869-no king 's court . There is , forsooth , [a folk that serveth [me]576-the lady or , it may be , more than one , of whom [thou]35-walter wert best to know nought . Of [others]113-others [I]576-the lady have but two servants , whom [thou]35-walter wilt see]1870-a folk that serveth me or , it may be , more than one , of whom thou wert best to know nought . of others i have but two servants , whom thou wilt see ; and [the one]1872-the one is [a strange creature , who should scare [thee]35-walter or scathe [thee]35-walter with a good will , but of a good will shall serve nought save [me]576-the lady]1873-a strange creature , who should scare thee or scathe thee with a good will , but of a good will shall serve nought save me ; the other is [a woman , a thrall , of little avail]1874-a woman , a thrall , of little avail , save that , being compelled , [she]1874-a woman , a thrall , of little avail will work [woman]1875-woman 's service for [me]576-the lady , but whom [none else shall compel . . . Yea]1876-none else shall compel . . . yea , but what is all this to [thee]35-walter ; or to [me]576-the lady that [I]576-the lady should tell it to [thee]35-walter ? [I]576-the lady will not drive [thee]35-walter away ; but if thine entertainment please [thee]35-walter not , make no plaint thereof to [me]576-the lady , but depart at [thy]35-walter will . Now is this talk betwixt [us]1877-us overlong , since , as [thou]35-walter seest , [I]576-the lady and [this King 's Son]1878-this king 's son are in converse together . Art [thou]35-walter [a King 's Son]1879-a king 's son ? "[576-the lady]

" Nay , [Lady]1863-lady , "[35-walter] said [Walter]35-walter , " [I]35-walter am but of [the sons of [the merchants]240-the merchants]1881-the sons of the merchants . "[35-walter]

" It matters not , "[584-she] [she]584-she said ; " go [thy]35-walter ways into [one of [the chambers]1884-the chambers]1883-one of the chambers . "[584-she]

And straightway [she]584-she fell a - talking to [the man who sat beside [her]584-she concerning the singing of the birds beneath [her]584-she window in the morning]585-the man who sat beside her concerning the singing of the birds beneath her window in the morning ; and of how [she]584-she had bathed [her]584-she that day in [a pool of [the woodlands]587-the woodlands]586-a pool of the woodlands , when [she]584-she had been heated with hunting , and so forth ; and all as if there had been none there save [her]584-she and [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son .

But [Walter]35-walter departed all ashamed , as though [he]35-walter had been [a poor man thrust away from [a rich kinsman]591-a rich kinsman 's door]590-a poor man thrust away from a rich kinsman 's door ; and [he]35-walter said to [himself]35-walter that [this woman]592-this woman was hateful , and nought love - worthy , and that [she]592-this woman was little like to tempt [him]35-walter , despite all the fairness of [her]592-this woman body .

[No one else]593-no one else [he]35-walter saw in [the house that even]594-the house that even ; [he]35-walter found meat and drink duly served on a fair table , and thereafter [he]35-walter came on a goodly bed , and all things needful , but [no child of Adam]595-no child of adam to do [him]35-walter service , or bid [him]35-walter welcome or warning . Nevertheless [he]35-walter ate , and drank , and slept , and put off thought of all these things till the morrow , all the more as [he]35-walter hoped to see [the kind maiden]596-the kind maiden some time betwixt sunrise and sunset on that new day .

CHAPTER XII : THE WEARING OF FOUR DAYS IN [THE WOOD]14-the wood BEYOND [THE WORLD]1-the world

[He]35-walter arose betimes , but found [no one]597-no one to greet [him]35-walter , neither was there any sound of [folk]598-folk moving within [the fair house]599-the fair house ; so [he]35-walter but broke [his]35-walter fast , and then went forth and wandered amongst the trees , till [he]35-walter found [him]35-walter a stream to bathe in , and after [he]35-walter had washed the night off [him]35-walter [he]35-walter lay down under a tree thereby for a while , but soon turned back toward [the house]112-the house , lest perchance [the Maid]543-the maid should come thither and [he]35-walter should miss [her]543-the maid .

It should be said that half a bow - shot from [the house]112-the house on that side i.e. due north thereof was [a little hazel - brake]603-a little hazel - brake , and round about it the trees were smaller of kind than the oaks and chestnuts [he]35-walter had passed through before , being mostly of birch and quicken - beam and young ash , with small wood betwixt them ; so now [he]35-walter passed through the thicket , and , coming to the edge thereof , beheld [the Lady]576-the lady and [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son walking together hand in hand , full lovingly by seeming .

[He]35-walter deemed it unmeet to draw back and hide [him]35-walter , so [he]35-walter went forth past [them]607-them toward [the house]112-the house . [[The King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son scowled on [him]35-walter as [he]35-walter passed , but [the Lady , over whose beauteous face flickered the joyous morning smiles]611-the lady , over whose beauteous face flickered the joyous morning smiles , took no more heed of [him]35-walter than if [he]35-walter had been one of [the trees of [the wood]1758-the wood]612-the trees of the wood . But [she]611-the lady , over whose beauteous face flickered the joyous morning smiles had been so high and disdainful with [him]35-walter the evening before , that [he]35-walter thought little of that . [The twain]201-the twain went on , skirting the hazel - copse , and [he]35-walter could not choose but turn [his]35-walter eyes on them , so sorely did [the Lady]576-the lady 's beauty draw them . Then befell another thing ; for behind [them]607-them the boughs of the hazels parted , and there stood that little evil thing , [he]616-he or another of [[his]35-walter kind]617-his kind ; for [he]35-walter was quite unclad , save by [his]35-walter fell of yellowy- brown hair , and that [he]35-walter was girt with a leathern girdle , wherein was stuck an ugly two - edged knife : [he]35-walter stood upright a moment , and cast [his]35-walter eyes at [Walter]35-walter and grinned , but not as if [he]35-walter knew [him]35-walter ; and scarce could [Walter]35-walter say whether it were the one [he]35-walter had seen , or another : then [he]35-walter cast [himself]35-walter down on [his]35-walter belly , and fell to creeping through the long grass like a serpent , following the footsteps of [the Lady]576-the lady and [[her]576-the lady lover]619-her lover ; and now , as [he]35-walter crept , [Walter]35-walter deemed , in [his]35-walter loathing , that the creature was liker to a ferret than aught else . [He]35-walter crept on marvellous swiftly , and was soon clean out of sight . But [Walter]35-walter stood staring after [him]35-walter for a while , and then lay down by the copse - side , that [he]35-walter might watch [the house]112-the house and the entry thereof ; for [he]35-walter thought , now perchance presently will [the kind maiden]596-the kind maiden come hither to comfort [me]0-i with a word or two . But hour passed by hour , and still [she]576-the lady came not ; and still [he]35-walter lay there , and thought of [the Maid]543-the maid , and longed for [her]543-the maid kindness and wisdom , till [he]35-walter could not refrain [his]35-walter tears , and wept for the lack of [her]543-the maid . Then [he]35-walter arose , and went and sat in [the porch]567-the porch , and was very downcast of mood .

But as [he]35-walter sat there , back comes [the Lady]576-the lady again , [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son leading [her]576-the lady by the hand ; [they]627-they entered [the porch]567-the porch , and [she]576-the lady passed by [him]35-walter so close that the odour of [her]576-the lady raiment filled all the air about [him]35-walter , and the sleekness of [her]576-the lady side nigh touched [him]35-walter , so that [he]35-walter could not fail to note that [her]576-the lady garments were somewhat disarrayed , and that [she]576-the lady kept [her]576-the lady right hand for [her]576-the lady left [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son held to [her]576-the lady bosom to hold the cloth together there , whereas the rich raiment had been torn off from [her]576-the lady right shoulder . As [they]627-they passed by [him]35-walter , [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son once more scowled on [him]35-walter , wordless , but even more fiercely than before ; and again [the Lady]576-the lady heeded [him]35-walter nought .

After [they]627-they had gone on a while , [he]35-walter entered [the hall]1860-the hall , and found [it]1860-the hall empty from end to end , and no sound in it save the tinkling of the fountain ; but there was victual set on the board . [He]35-walter ate and drank thereof to keep life lusty within [him]35-walter , and then went out again to the wood - side to watch and to long ; and the time hung heavy on [his]35-walter hands because of the lack of [the fair Maiden]635-the fair maiden .

[He]35-walter was of mind not to go into [the house]112-the house to [his]35-walter rest that night , but to sleep under the boughs of [the forest]637-the forest . But a little after sunset [he]35-walter saw a bright - clad image moving amidst the carven images of [the porch]567-the porch , and [the King 's Son]1781-the king 's son came forth and went straight to [him]35-walter , and said : " [Thou]1885-thy art to enter [the house]112-the house , and go into [[thy]1885-thy chamber]1887-thy chamber forthwith , and by no means to go forth of it betwixt sunset and sunrise . [[My]1781-the king 's son Lady]1767-my lady will not away with [thy]1885-thy prowling round [the house]112-the house in the night - tide . "[1781-the king 's son]

Therewith [he]1781-the king 's son turned away , and went into [the house]112-the house again ; and [Walter]35-walter followed [him]1781-the king 's son soberly , remembering how [the Maid]543-the maid had bidden [him]35-walter forbear . So [he]35-walter went to [[his]35-walter chamber]259-his chamber , and slept .

But amidst of the night [he]35-walter awoke and deemed that [he]35-walter heard a voice not far off , so [he]35-walter crept out of [his]35-walter bed and peered around , lest , perchance , [the Maid]543-the maid had come to speak with [him]35-walter ; but [[his]35-walter chamber]259-his chamber was dusk and empty : then [he]35-walter went to the window and looked out , and saw the moon shining bright and white upon the greensward . And lo ! [the Lady]576-the lady walking with [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son , and [he]1781-the king 's son clad in thin and wanton raiment , but [she]576-the lady in nought else save what [God]44-god had given [her]576-the lady of long , crispy yellow hair . Then was [Walter]35-walter ashamed to look on [her]576-the lady , seeing that there was [a man]229-a man with [her]576-the lady , and gat [him]1781-the king 's son back to [his]35-walter bed ; but yet a long while ere [he]35-walter slept again [he]35-walter had the image before [his]35-walter eyes of [the fair woman]649-the fair woman on the dewy moonlit grass .

The next day matters went much the same way , and the next also , save that [his]35-walter sorrow was increased , and [he]35-walter sickened sorely of hope deferred . On the fourth day also [the forenoon]650-the forenoon wore as erst ; but in the heat of the afternoon [Walter]35-walter sought to [the hazel - copse]651-the hazel - copse , and laid [him]1781-the king 's son down there hard by [a little clearing thereof]652-a little clearing thereof , and slept from very weariness of grief . There , after a while , [he]35-walter woke with words still hanging in [his]35-walter ears , and [he]35-walter knew at once that it was [they]653-they twain talking together .

[[The King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son had just done [his]1781-the king 's son say , and now it was [the Lady]576-the lady beginning in [her]576-the lady honey - sweet voice , low but strong , wherein even was a little of huskiness ; [she]576-the lady said : " [Otto]57-otto , belike it were well to have a little patience , till [we]653-they find out what [the man]1710-the man is , and whence [he]1710-the man cometh ; it will always be easy to rid [us]653-they of [him]1710-the man ; it is but a word to [[our]653-they Dwarf - king]1891-our dwarf - king , and it will be done in a few minutes . "[576-the lady]

" Patience ! "[1780-the king] said [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son , angrily ; " [I]1780-the king wot not how to have patience with [him]1710-the man ; for [I]1780-the king can see of [him]1710-the man that [he]1710-the man is rude and violent and headstrong , and [a low - born wily one]1892-a low - born wily one . [Forsooth]58-forsooth , [he]1710-the man had patience enough with [me]1780-the king the other even , when [I]1780-the king rated [him]1710-the man in , like the dog that [he]1710-the man is , and [he]1710-the man had no manhood to say one word to [me]1780-the king . Soothly , as [he]1710-the man followed after [me]1780-the king , [I]1780-the king had a mind to turn about and deal [him]1710-the man a buffet on the face , to see if [I]1780-the king could but draw one angry word from [him]1710-the man . "[1780-the king]

[The Lady]576-the lady laughed , and said : " Well , [Otto]57-otto , [I]576-the lady know not ; that which [thou]1893-thou deemest dastardy in [him]1710-the man may be but prudence and wisdom , and [he]1710-the man an alien , far from [[his]1710-the man friends]1894-his friends and nigh to [[his]1710-the man foes]1895-his foes . Perchance [we]1896-we shall yet try [him]1710-the man what [he]1710-the man is . Meanwhile , [I]576-the lady rede [thee]1893-thou try [him]1710-the man not with buffets , save [he]1710-the man be weaponless and with bounden hands ; or else [I]576-the lady deem that but a little while shalt [thou]1893-thou be fain of [thy]1893-thou blow . "[576-the lady]

Now when [Walter]35-walter heard [her]660-her words and the voice wherein they were said , [he]35-walter might not forbear being stirred by them , and to [him]35-walter , all lonely there , [they]661-they seemed friendly .

But [he]35-walter lay still , and [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son answered [the Lady]576-the lady and said : " [I]1781-the king 's son know not what is in thine heart concerning this runagate , that [thou]1893-thou shouldst bemock [me]1781-the king 's son with [his]1710-the man valiancy , whereof [thou]1893-thou knowest nought . If [thou]1893-thou deem [me]1781-the king 's son unworthy of [thee]1893-thou , send [me]1781-the king 's son back safe to [[[my]1781-the king 's son father]1578-my father 's country]1898-my father 's country ; [I]1781-the king 's son may look to have worship there ; yea , and the love of [fair women]1899-fair women belike . "[1781-the king 's son]

Therewith it seemed as if [he]35-walter had put forth [his]35-walter hand to [the Lady]576-the lady to caress [her]576-the lady , for [she]576-the lady said : " Nay , lay not thine hand on [my]576-the lady shoulder , for to - day and now it is not the hand of love , but of pride and folly , and would - be mastery . Nay , neither shalt [thou]1893-thou rise up and leave [me]576-the lady until [thy]1893-thou mood is softer and kinder to [me]576-the lady . "[576-the lady]

Then was there silence betwixt [them]666-them a while , and thereafter [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son spake in a wheedling voice : " [[My]1781-the king 's son goddess]1900-my goddess , [I]1781-the king 's son pray [thee]1900-my goddess pardon [me]1781-the king 's son ! But canst [thou]1893-thou wonder that [I]1781-the king 's son fear [thy]1893-thou wearying of [me]1781-the king 's son , and am therefore peevish and jealous ? [thou]1893-thou so far above [the Queens of [the World]1-the world]1901-the queens of the world , and [I]1781-the king 's son [a poor youth]1902-a poor youth that without [thee]1893-thou were nothing ! "[1781-the king 's son]

[She]669-she answered nought , and [he]1781-the king 's son went on again : " Was it not so , [O goddess]1903-o goddess , that [this man of the sons of the merchants]1904-this man of the sons of the merchants was little heedful of [thee]1893-thou , and [thy]1893-thou loveliness and [[thy]1893-thou majesty]1905-thy majesty ? "[1781-the king 's son]

[She]669-she laughed and said : " Maybe [he]1904-this man of the sons of the merchants deemed not that [he]1904-this man of the sons of the merchants had much to gain of [us]1906-us , seeing [thee]1893-thou sitting by [our]1906-us side , and whereas [we]1906-us spake to [him]1904-this man of the sons of the merchants coldly and sternly and disdainfully . [Withal]59-withal , [the poor youth]1907-the poor youth was dazzled and shamefaced before [us]1906-us ; that [we]1906-us could see in the eyes and [the mien of [him]1904-this man of the sons of the merchants]1908-the mien of him . "[669-she]

Now this [she]669-she spoke so kindly and sweetly , that again was [Walter]35-walter all stirred thereat ; and it came into [his]35-walter mind that it might be [she]669-she knew [he]35-walter was anigh and hearing [her]669-she , and that [she]669-she spake as much for [him]35-walter as for [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son : but [that one]672-that one answered : " [Lady]1863-lady , didst [thou]1910-thou not see somewhat else in [his]35-walter eyes , to wit , that [they]1911-they had but of late looked on [some fair woman other than [thee]1910-thou]1912-some fair woman other than thee ? As for [me]669-she , [I]669-she deem it not so unlike that on the way to [thine hall]1913-thine hall [he]35-walter may have fallen in with [[thy]1910-thou Maid]1914-thy maid . "[669-she]

[He]35-walter spoke in a faltering voice , as if shrinking from some storm that might come . And forsooth [the Lady]576-the lady 's voice was changed as [she]576-the lady answered , though there was no outward heat in it ; rather it was sharp and eager and cold at once . [She]576-the lady said : " [Yea]1915-yea , that is not ill thought of ; but [we]1916-we may not always keep [our]1916-we thrall in mind . If it be so as [thou]1910-thou deemest , [we]1916-we shall come to know it most like when [we]1916-we next fall in with [her]1914-thy maid ; or if [she]1914-thy maid hath been shy this time , then shall [she]1914-thy maid pay the heavier for it ; for [we]1916-we will question [her]1914-thy maid by the Fountain in [the Hall]1860-the hall as to what betid by the Fountain of the Rock . "[576-the lady]

Spake [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son , faltering yet more : " [Lady]1863-lady , were it not better to question [the man]1710-the man [himself]1710-the man ? [the Maid]543-the maid is stout - hearted , and will not be speedily quelled into a true tale ; whereas [the man]1710-the man [I]576-the lady deem of no account . "[576-the lady]

" No , no , "[576-the lady] said [the Lady]576-the lady sharply , " it shall not be . "[576-the lady]

Then was [she]576-the lady silent a while ; and then [she]576-the lady said : " How if [the man]1710-the man should prove to be [[our]1916-we master]1923-our master ? "[576-the lady]

" Nay , [[our]1916-we Lady]1924-our lady , "[1780-the king] said [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son , " [thou]1925-thou art jesting with [me]1780-the king ; [thou]1925-thou and [thy]1925-thou might and [thy]1925-thou wisdom , and all that [thy]1925-thou wisdom may command , to be over- mastered by [a gangrel churl]1926-a gangrel churl ! "[1780-the king]

" But how if [I]576-the lady will not have it command , [[King]1927-king 's Son]1928-king 's son ? "[576-the lady] said [the Lady]576-the lady . " [I]576-the lady tell [thee]1925-thou [I]576-the lady know [thine]1925-thou heart , but [thou]1925-thou knowest not [mine]576-the lady . But be at peace ! For since [thou]1925-thou hast prayed for [this woman]592-this woman - nay , not with [thy]1925-thou words , [I]576-the lady wot , but with [thy]1925-thou trembling hands , and thine anxious eyes , and knitted brow - [I]576-the lady say , since [thou]1925-thou hast prayed for [her]592-this woman so earnestly , [she]592-this woman shall escape this time . But whether it will be to [her]592-this woman gain in the long run , [I]576-the lady misdoubt [me]576-the lady . See [thou]1925-thou to that , [Otto]57-otto ! [thou]1925-thou who hast held [me]576-the lady in thine arms so oft . And now [thou]1925-thou mayest depart if [thou]1925-thou wilt . "[576-the lady]

It seemed to [Walter]35-walter as if [[the King]1780-the king 's Son]1781-the king 's son were dumbfoundered at [her]682-her words : [he]1781-the king 's son answered nought , and presently [he]1781-the king 's son rose from the ground , and went [his]1781-the king 's son ways slowly toward [the house]112-the house . [The Lady]576-the lady lay there a little while , and then went [her]576-the lady ways also ; but turned away from [the house]112-the house toward the wood at the other end thereof , whereby [Walter]35-walter had first come thither .

As for [Walter]35-walter , [he]35-walter was confused in mind and shaken in spirit ; and withal [he]35-walter seemed to see guile and cruel deeds under the talk of [those two]686-those two , and waxed wrathful thereat . Yet [he]35-walter said to [himself]35-walter , that nought might [he]35-walter do , but was as one bound hand and foot , till [he]35-walter had seen [the Maid]543-the maid again .

CHAPTER XIII : NOW IS THE HUNT UP

Next morning was [he]35-walter up betimes , but [he]35-walter was cast down and heavy of heart , not looking for aught else to betide than had betid those last four days . But otherwise it fell out ; for when [he]35-walter came down into [the hall]1860-the hall , there was [the lady sitting on the high - seat]689-the lady sitting on the high - seat all alone , clad but in a coat of white linen ; and [she]689-the lady sitting on the high - seat turned [her]689-the lady sitting on the high - seat head when [she]689-the lady sitting on the high - seat heard [his]35-walter footsteps , and looked on [him]35-walter , and greeted [him]35-walter , and said : " Come hither , [guest]1930-guest . "[689-the lady sitting on the high - seat]

So [he]35-walter went and stood before [her]689-the lady sitting on the high - seat , and [she]689-the lady sitting on the high - seat said : " Though as yet [thou]1931-thou hast had no welcome here , and no honour , it hath not entered into thine heart to flee from [us]1932-our ; and to say sooth , that is well for [thee]1931-thou , for flee away from [our]1932-our hand [thou]1931-thou mightest not , nor mightest [thou]1931-thou depart without [our]1932-our furtherance . But for this [we]1932-our can [thee]1931-thou thank , that [thou]1931-thou hast abided here [our]1932-our bidding and eaten thine heart through the heavy wearing of four days , and made no plaint . Yet [I]689-the lady sitting on the high - seat can not deem [thee]1931-thou a dastard ; [thou]1931-thou [so well knit and shapely of body , so clear - eyed and bold of visage]1933-so well knit and shapely of body , so clear - eyed and bold of visage . Wherefore now [I]689-the lady sitting on the high - seat ask [thee]1931-thou , art [thou]1931-thou willing to do [me]689-the lady sitting on the high - seat service , thereby to earn [thy]1931-thou guesting ? "[689-the lady sitting on the high - seat]

[Walter]35-walter answered [her]690-me , somewhat faltering at first , for [he]35-walter was astonished at the change which had come over [her]690-me ; for now [she]690-me spoke to [him]35-walter in friendly wise , though indeed as [a great lady]691-a great lady would speak to [a young man]87-a young man ready to serve [her]690-me in all honour . Said [he]35-walter : " [Lady]1863-lady , [I]35-walter can thank [thee]1863-lady humbly and heartily in that [thou]1863-lady biddest [me]35-walter do [thee]1863-lady service ; for these days past [I]35-walter have loathed the emptiness of the hours , and nought better could [I]35-walter ask for than to serve [so glorious a Mistress]1935-so glorious a mistress in all honour . "[35-walter]

[She]690-me frowned somewhat , and said : " [Thou]1863-lady shalt not call [me]690-me [Mistress]1936-mistress ; there is but one who so calleth [me]690-me , that is [my]690-me thrall ; and [thou]1863-lady art none such . [Thou]1863-lady shalt call [me]690-me [Lady]1863-lady , and [I]690-me shall be well pleased that [thou]1863-lady be [[my]690-me squire]1938-my squire , and for this present [thou]1863-lady shalt serve [me]690-me in the hunting . So get [thy]1863-lady gear ; take [thy]1863-lady bow and arrows , and gird [thee]1863-lady to [thy]1863-lady sword . For in [this fair land]1939-this fair land may [one]1940-one find beasts more perilous than be buck or hart . [I]690-me go now to array [me]690-me ; [we]1941-we will depart while the day is yet young ; for so make [we]1941-we the summer day the fairest . "[690-me]

[He]693-he made obeisance to [her]694-her , and [she]694-her arose and went to [[her]694-her chamber]695-her chamber , and [Walter]35-walter dight [himself]35-walter , and then abode [her]694-her in [the porch]567-the porch ; and in less than an hour [she]694-her came out of [the hall]1860-the hall , and [Walter]35-walter 's heart beat when [he]35-walter saw that [the Maid]543-the maid followed [her]694-her hard at heel , and scarce might [he]35-walter school [his]35-walter eyes not to gaze over - eagerly at [[his]35-walter dear friend]699-his dear friend . [She]543-the maid was clad even as [she]543-the maid was before , and was changed in no wise , save that love troubled [her]543-the maid face when [she]543-the maid first beheld [him]35-walter , and [she]543-the maid had much ado to master it : howbeit [the Mistress]1828-the mistress heeded not the trouble of [her]543-the maid , or made no semblance of heeding it , till [the Maiden]183-the maiden 's face was all according to its wo nt .

But this [Walter]35-walter found strange , that after all that disdain of [the Maid]543-the maid 's thralldom which [he]35-walter had heard of [the Mistress]1828-the mistress , and after all the threats against [her]1828-the mistress , now was [the Mistress]1828-the mistress become mild and debonaire to [her]1828-the mistress , as [a good lady to [[her]1828-the mistress good maiden]706-her good maiden]705-a good lady to her good maiden . When [Walter]35-walter bowed the knee to [her]543-the maid , [she]543-the maid turned unto [the Maid]543-the maid , and said : " Look [thou]543-the maid , [[my]543-the maid Maid]1942-my maid , at [this fair new Squire]1943-this fair new squire that [I]543-the maid have gotten ! Will not [he]1943-this fair new squire be valiant in the greenwood ? And see whether [he]1943-this fair new squire be well shapen or not . Doth [he]1943-this fair new squire not touch [thine]543-the maid heart , when [thou]543-the maid thinkest of all the woe , and fear , and trouble of [the World beyond [the Wood]14-the wood]1944-the world beyond the wood , which [he]1943-this fair new squire hath escaped , to dwell in [this little land]1945-this little land peaceably , and well - beloved both by [the Mistress]1828-the mistress and [the Maid]543-the maid ? And [thou]543-the maid , [[my]543-the maid Squire]1938-my squire , look a little at [this fair slim Maiden]1949-this fair slim maiden , and say if [she]1949-this fair slim maiden pleaseth [thee]35-walter not : didst [thou]543-the maid deem that [we]1950-we had any thing so fair in [this lonely place]1951-this lonely place ? "[543-the maid]

[Frank]60-frank and kind was the smile on [her]708-her radiant visage , nor did [she]708-her seem to note any whit the trouble on [Walter]35-walter 's face , nor how [he]35-walter strove to keep [his]35-walter eyes from [the Maid]543-the maid . As for [her]708-her , [she]708-her had so wholly mastered [her]708-her countenance , that belike [she]708-her used [her]708-her face guilefully , for [she]708-her stood as one humble but happy , with a smile on [her]708-her face , blushing , and with [her]708-her head hung down as if shamefaced before [a goodly young man]710-a goodly young man , [a stranger]711-a stranger .

But [the Lady]576-the lady looked upon [her]708-her kindly and said : " Come hither , [child]1564-child , and fear not [this frank and free young man]1953-this frank and free young man , who belike feareth [thee]1564-child a little , and full certainly feareth [me]576-the lady ; and yet only after the manner of [men]165-men . "[576-the lady]

And therewith [she]576-the lady took [the Maid]543-the maid by the hand and drew [her]543-the maid to [her]576-the lady , and pressed [her]543-the maid to [her]576-the lady bosom , and kissed [her]543-the maid cheeks and [her]543-the maid lips , and undid the lacing of [her]543-the maid gown and bared a shoulder of [her]543-the maid , and swept away [her]543-the maid skirt from [her]543-the maid feet ; and then turned to [Walter]35-walter and said : " Lo [thou]35-walter , [Squire]61-squire ! is not this a lovely thing to have grown up amongst [our]1955-our rough oak- boles ? What ! art [thou]35-walter looking at the iron ring there ? It is nought , save a token that [she]543-the maid is [mine]35-walter , and that [I]35-walter may not be without [her]543-the maid . "[35-walter]

Then [she]543-the maid took [the Maid]543-the maid by the shoulders and turned [her]543-the maid about as in sport , and said : " Go [thou]35-walter now , and bring hither [the good grey ones]1956-the good grey ones ; for needs must [we]1955-our bring home some venison to - day , whereas [this stout warrior]1957-this stout warrior may not feed on nought save manchets and honey . "[543-the maid]

So [the Maid]543-the maid went [her]543-the maid way , taking care , as [Walter]35-walter deemed , to give no side glance to [him]35-walter . But [he]35-walter stood there shamefaced , so confused with all this openhearted kindness of [the great Lady]716-the great lady and with the fresh sight of the darling beauty of [the Maid]543-the maid , that [he]35-walter went nigh to thinking that all [he]35-walter had heard since [he]35-walter had come to [the porch of [the house]112-the house]718-the porch of the house that first time was but a dream of evil .

But while [he]35-walter stood pondering these matters , and staring before [him]35-walter as [one mazed]720-one mazed , [the Lady]576-the lady laughed out in [his]35-walter face , and touched [him]35-walter on the arm and said : " Ah , [[our]1955-our Squire]1958-our squire , is it so that now [thou]1959-thou hast seen [[my]576-the lady Maid]1942-my maid [thou]1959-thou wouldst with a good will abide behind to talk with [her]1942-my maid ? But call to mind [thy]1942-my maid word pledged to [me]576-the lady e'en now ! And moreover [I]576-the lady tell [thee]1942-my maid this for [thy]1942-my maid behoof now [she]1942-my maid is out of ear - shot , that [I]576-the lady will above all things take [thee]1942-my maid away to - day : for there be other eyes , and [they]1961-they nought uncomely , that look at whiles on [my]576-the lady fair - ankled thrall ; and who knows but the swords might be out if [I]576-the lady take not the better heed , and give [thee]1942-my maid not every whit of [thy]1942-my maid will . "[576-the lady]
